149891303.review:
As can be told from the hours played, I have played this game a [i]fair[/i] bit, so this review is with what I would like to think is with a fairly high grasp of the nuances and quirks of CVR. (To say, there's more to unpack than the 0.2hr reviews will let on because those users have no patience.)

As a start, yes, VRChat. As many, [i]many[/i] users both inside and out of CVR like to compare to VRChat, this review will be no different in that regard. On the surface, there is a fairly large amount of overlap with what that game is and does. On the surface. Where CVR differences shine in the current require digging into the minutia of what CVR has to offer, which you will not get on a casual visit, so please keep that in mind if we want to try the game for the first time. The devs of CVR want the game to become more of its own thing over time (Think CVR eventually being the Geocities to VRC's Facebook), but I can't review a game for what it wants to be, only what it is now.

Also for context, yes, I was also one of the many who was rather disgruntled with VRChat's decision to include EAC into a [i]social VR game[/i], and decided that outside of very specific circumstances was leaving that behind. Not to say you [i]have[/i] to only play one game or the other, I just personally choose to play CVR over VRC as EAC is a non-starter for giving-a-minor-s###-about-my-personal-security reasons. (VRC is exclusively played on a secondary sacrificial machine, or on Linux, now for example.)
The difference was I actually commit to things when I say “I'm done with this”.

With that out of the way,

[h3]Playerbase[/h3]
Yes, it is smaller than VRChat. That is a fact. But, bigger numbers are not the end-all be-all of quality. Frankly, far from it.

The best way I can describe ChilloutVR in that regard is to imagine the difference between living in a village vs. living in a major city.
In a city, you are never going to meet everyone, there's a lot more room for bad actors to play off “Hiding in obscurity”, and people naturally will hole up in smaller groups of friends and family, becoming a nesting doll of otherwise completely separate groups. With the only real interaction any individual will have to the wider whole of the population being what a given individual contributes to that city physically. Though due to that, there are great wide variety of things to do in that city.
In contrast, in a small village, everyone who lives there knows, or at least is aware of, everyone else that lives there. It's not bustling in overflow like the big city, but it more than makes up for in mutual comradery and a natural filter for the aforementioned bad actors as you're not going to last long if you're trying to ruin everyone else's day. Which results in a far greater quality to the fewer individuals on average you run into with the less in quantity.
So if the idea of a “Community”, in the genuine organic sense instead of the meaningless buzzword sense, is something that appeals, then CVR's for you.

Getting away from the metaphor, there is a very dedicated regular playerbase to CVR. The thing though, it has its peak times and it has its dead times. You can not jump on literally whenever and expect to get a fair gauge of what the playerbase is like, that's just not how it works. During the evenings EU time, and far more so in the evening/late night USA time are when the most people are going to be on, with Tue/Thu/Sun being the dead days of the week, with Mon/Wed/Fri/Sat being the more active days, Saturday night USA time when the Viviklub is running being the peak of the week. If you wish to give CVR a fair shake, I would recommend getting on peak times specifically as when I say CVR is dead during the off times and days of the week, it is [i]dead[/i]. It's the nature of a more concentrated playerbase, it naturally necessitates this kind of clustering of when people are on.

Also, as of current no Quest kiddies, so while eventual Pico/Quest support will be a thing, in the moment the lack of support is a hard filter to the worst of [i]that[/i] problem. 

[h3]The UI[/h3]
This is in here due to the great many complaints about it in the other reviews. Frankly, those complaints seem largely disingenuous. Do I think the UI of CVR is good? [i]F### no.[/i] It has a [i]lot[/i] of usability and legacy crust to resolve, which is going to come in due time as of the writing of this review. But the reason why I say most of the complaints of CVR's menus are disingenuous, I have largely the exact same kinds of complaints about VRChat's UI decisions, to the point whenever I find myself there once in a blue moon, I'm sitting there confounded at where the f### anything is or how to use them.
Which is a common scenario going from any given software to another. Talk to a disgruntled Maya user trying to use Blender for another example of this.
The thing is, anyone who has played VRC for a extended period of time and is used to how they do things has been “Boil the frog”'d into their mindset and methodology for how to do a UI, and find it difficult to adjust to a different paradigm. Some of which is actual jank that needs to be fixed up do not get me wrong, but the exact same could be said about VRChat's. Except CVR's devs acknowledge it needs to be fixed up, while VRC flat out ignores it's a problem and think it's perfect.

[h3]User Creation[/h3]
As I'm coming from a avatar, and by extension now the occasional prop, making background with VRC, [i]holy f### is making avatars in CVR [b]SO[/b] much better than trying to do it in VRC.[/i]
No absurdly low networked parameter limit, you actually have [i]ROOM[/i] to do cool things on your avatars.
Props being a thing means [i]significantly[/i] less screwing around with world constraints or having to do repeat work for multiple avatars.
The actual setup in general is FAR less of a faff, no 5 different animators and two other random files to set up avatars properly.
Components that are WAY more useful when you find out they exist.

I could go on, but that all is with a caveat: The documentation for most of this in the current is non-existent, with most of the actual knowledge for how to do things coming from some basic youtube tutorials, and asking in the ABI (company running CVR) discord for anything more advanced. This has been a ongoing thing that people have tried to address, but as of the writing it's a case of “Bigger fish to fry”, which with CVR's need for development in certain areas still, I get, but is never-the-less a issue that needs to be resolved. Which I have full confidence it will, just again I can only review the here and now.

Despite the caveat, there's also things like the water buoyancy system that was newly introduced, freaking amazing cloth physics by way of Magica Cloth (2), and a bunch of other things coming that make this all a “Once we get how the paradigm of how things work in CVR, there's SO much that can be done that a certain other game doesn't/won't/[i]can't[/i] do it's insane.”

(Continued in the comments.)

Do you leave what you know, and potentially all the people you're familiar with, for a place that, while you certainly will get used to overtime, you're unfamiliar with?
Are you willing to put in the effort to rebuild your presence in a new space that's still small and fresh, or stay in an environment that you're familiar with and can navigate better socially?

146679502.review:
800+ hours spent (at the time this review was written) playing this game and it feels like time well spent. I showed up to the community shortly after the controversy broke out regarding VRChat's update adding EAC and banning mods all together. Not as a refugee, mind you, I have had no prior experience with VRChat or anything else like it before that update but after having seen some people recommend this game over VRC, I was curious and decided to check it out and boy oh boy am I glad I did. I was hooked on this right away. Why? The main reason: the community itself. While it is very small compared to VRC, 9 times out of 10 you'll find a friendly face that you can strike up a conversation and goof around with too. Of course there is some bad actors you likely come across but those are few and far in between, in my entire time playing this I've only encountered 2 trolls and 1 crasher. Granted, I typically occupy instances that have low player counts but I digress. Fact of the matter, ChilloutVRs player base is a pleasant bunch of folks.

Chillout has a pretty unique feature for this genre of game called "props" which is publicly available community made content that anybody can spawn in and play around with much in the same sort of sense as you would expect with, say, Gmod. There's a wide variety of things the community has made from cars, guns, toys, furniture, food, pocket dimensions, writing utensils, meme based stuff, etc. You name it, you'll likely find it. 

The developers are actively working on this game and are doing their due diligence to make it the best it can be. It's a small dev team tho so of course updates are gonna be infrequent but they're trying and that's what matters. They recently started doing monthly blogs to keep everyone up to date on what they plan on doing and how they plan on doing it. You can even check out the AlphaBlendInteractive website to check out what they have done, what they're working on, and what they plan on doing. 

Unlike VRC after that one update, CVR has it's own mod support through the use of melon loader and ABI added in their previous update to the game something called the Mod Network What is it? "The Mod Network is a built-in networking layer that mod developers can utilize. It allows for Mods to communicate between Users in the same instance in a secure way without needing any third-party Networking library or services." So yeah. There you go. The modding community has made some well crafted mods that adds some some fun goofy features to the game or some much desired quality of life features as well so if you decided to try this game out. Don't hesitate to check out the mods as well! 

Of course with this game being early access, it's not gonna be the best experience out there. The previous update upgraded the game engine to a newer version which, of course, is gonna cause some issues with user made content. Mainly speaking in terms of the shaders used. As it currently stands, VR users are gonna suffer from this shader issue the most compared to the desktop users and there's no real certainty as to if the content makers are gonna fix this issue with their content as a large percentage of them have come and gone from what I can tell.  You wont find much in terms of interactive experiences across the various worlds you find, this is mainly due to absence of any sort of scripting to allow for custom interactive experiences to be possible but some users still have been able to get something done. The menu UI could be better, it's not terrible but I'd argue it could benefit from some improvements. 

TL;DR
-The community is friendly
-This game has user made item content you can spawn in and play around with
-The developers are actively improving upon this game.
-It has good mod support
-This game being in early access , it's has some flaws.

145366230.review:
[b]This review is outdated in at least one regard, possibly more, take it with a grain of salt because things have actually improved further.[/b]

I recently looked at the reviews for this game and noticed how negative they've been recently, so I figured I'd put my feedback in too... [b]TL;DR: It's probably not ready to replace VRChat just yet, but keep an eye on it because it correctly does everything that has bothered VRChat users for years.[/b]


I won't sugarcoat it, [b]THIS GAME IS DEFINITELY EARLY ACCESS.[/b]

The negative reviews are right that the UI needs a LOT of work and that the already limited community content was further reduced by the recent Unity upgrade. [strike]It's features are also relatively limited, it doesn't have the avatar interactions VRC has which I am especially disappointed by among many other things.[/strike] I've been informed that avatar interactions were actually added since I posted this review so that's good. I'll have to redo this thoroughly after I can find some time to play it again enough.

[h1] HOWEVER[/h1]
I see such an incredible amount of potential in this game and the devs behind it seem passionate enough to realize that potential with time. Some things that CVR even now does better that VRChat:
- [b]Performance:[/b] The best FPS I can get on VRChat is 40 on a good day, but more often it's more like 25... CVR gives me a consistent 60 minimum. 
- [b]Community Communication:[/b] The CVR team does an excellent job keeping the community up to date on what they're doing. They make monthly community posts here on steam describing update progress. Versus VRChat that dropped news of a universally hated update mere days before it went live.
- [b]Modding:[/b] CVR actually supports it! And mods currently implement a good number of things the base game doesn't yet.
- [b]Handling of Mature Content:[/b] Mature content isn't outright banned on CVR. It is hidden behind a free DLC with the mature tag. People who want to see mature content are free to do so while those who don't want to see it don't need to. And, assuming their parents setup parental controls on their child's Steam account, kids still can't access it.
Overall, CVR just gives a far better impression towards its users. It feels like they actually care. Again, CVR is definitely still lacking in terms of featureset and content, I won't deny that. But it's still early access, the limited features will be resolved with a bit more time, and then it's up to us to fix the content issue.

[h1]My Recommendation[/h1]
Put it in your library and keep an eye on their posts. Check back every few months and see if it's gotten anything you really want from VRChat. Recent posts seem to suggest that they're poised to move towards more feature updates soon.

143796137.review:
This is a tough one for me. It is promising as a platform, but in its current state, i dont see any reason to ditch VRChat. Here are my issues (specifically in comparing it to VRChat)

1: The UI is definitely worse. Its very hard to figure out how to do things at first, and i still struggle with certain parts. VRChat is way more user friendly.
2: There isnt a player base.  Its hard to join a VR community that essentially barely exists. I have not seen more than 50 people online at any given time.
3: A recent upgrade to Unity ChillOutVR implemented screwed with a bunch of maps. Its cool that they allowed the older maps to exist, but they may as well have removed them, because a lot of them are barely playable due to the screwed up shaders, and it applies to some of the avatars too. Yeah, VRChat had a similar issue where they changed the SDK (i believe is what its called, their map creator) and decided to delete its older maps, but in doing that, meant that every map they had worked, where ChillOutVRs approach just makes the game look buggy and bad if you pick the wrong maps.
4: Some of its options are limited and confusing. My main issue is button mapping, which as far as im concerned, doesnt exist. The buttons on your controller and what they do cannot be changed. (And lord, i dont know why they made disabling finger tracking one of the main buttons and not just a option in the settings. I accidentally activate it all the time and its frustrating) Im not 100% sure this is the case, but i searched for a while, and the lack of guides online due to this games very small community makes navigating the options a bit hard.
5: This is more of a personal gripe, but the need to download a seperate DLC to view any avatar remotely NSFW, regardless if its something small that really isnt NSFW, is pretty stupid. Just have that be a thing you can change in the game, not be a seperate DLC. Its just an annoying and unnecessary step.

All this being said, there are some positives.

1: You can look up avatars rather than having to find a world to do that. Its way more conveinient doing it that way.
2: This same search bar can be used to look up props you can spawn into the world that vary in meme value and size. You can just shove a roller coaster into a world if you want, and i love that.
3: Im not a content creator myself, but ive heard its a lot more user friendly to upload maps and avatars into ChillOutVR, (though due to the new Unity update, most maps have to be upgraded).
4: Flying is a thing that comes automatically in the game, rather than having to look for specific avatars that do it, which is cool for maps you just want to screw around on. Though realistically, most maps will probably disable it.

Thats about it. Anything else i didnt mention, VRChat either does equally as good or better. ChillOutVR has a lot of promise, but i cannot see myself switching to it anytime soon. Heck, most/all of the maps i go to are maps that were ported from VRChat (which are all unplayable at the moment due to the unity upgrade by the way). Its fun to go into it in a one day journey, but then youll just stick to VRChat for everything else. Maybe one day ill be redoing this review if it gets better, but i just cannot reccomend this game for the long term at the moment at the moment.

140299807.review:
So, SO much better than VRChat. I've been searching for a replacement for VRChat for a while and can't believe I glossed over this one.
[list]
[*] Content creation is far more streamlined with far fewer limitations. I had zero issues getting an avatar and a world uploaded and working perfectly in the span of an hour or so.
[*] Native buttery smooth facetracking. No more complicated animator controllers and hacky ik-synced parameter workarounds.
[*] Avatars are much easier to configure and have far fewer limitations than VRChat avatars.
[*] Dynamic tagging system can selectively block specific components of others' avatars without needing to use a fallback.
[*] Modding supported and encouraged in line with terms of service. 
[*] Spawnable props remove the need to attach tools and items to each avatar itself.
[*] Camera is way easier to use and way more feature-rich. Drone mode allows you to fly the camera to where you want instead of positioning by hand.
[*] No subscriptions or crypto unlike other social VR platforms.
[*] Seems to be a scripting frontend in the works for avatar, prop, and world creation. 
[/list]

137786275.review:
(actual playtime is higher than what is shown on Steam)

In it's current state I can't recommend ChilloutVR.
- Logging into the game needs to be done on Desktop every time the game is started, without any support for seamless login through Steam. Resulting in awkwardly having to start the game, taking off the headset to log in, then putting on the headset again
- It's lacking the usercount to be a functional social VR Platform, which is what the game is trying to be.
- Most Worlds / Instances are just 1:1 copies of existing environments copied from the larger Platform "VRChat". Most of those worlds have a lot of features stripped from them as a result of lazy reuploading or lack of equivalent features in ChilloutVR.
- The game is lacking polish in a bunch of places, which is okay on its own, but becomes very obvious when compared to competitors like "VRChat" or "NeosVR"
- The website, which contains placeholders for a lot of neat ideas like avatar sharing, groups or a search function, has not received any visible updates or development on those placeholders in years.
- Their "roadmap" is just a kanban-board of bugfixes that are being worked on and doesn't contain any actual roadmap that would outline their long-term development plans or goals.

and the big one that I'll expand on a bit:
-NSFW content is gated behind an optional Steam-DLC.
This is a great idea in general, but this is the internet and most users predictably have NSFW-features on their avatars, meaning that this DLC is pretty much required to properly see and interact with a very large portion of the already small playerbase. The DLC is also unavailable in Germany, since Steam blocks erotic content there to comply with age-verification laws, resulting in german players being completely unable to see these avatars. The fallback avatars (which are the same robotic fallback avatars that VRChat uses) don't even scale to the same size as the blocked avatars, resulting in you not even looking at the person you're trying to have a conversation with.
Considering that the developers are based in Germany and offer no alternatives, it feels like a lazy solution by them to avoid dealing with those laws themselves and shifting blame for the problem towards Valve.

137621679.review: ChilloutVR offers a virtual reality experience that is different from VRChat, with its own unique features and community. The game provides a relaxed and chill social atmosphere, with a focus on exploration and creativity rather than competitive gaming or roleplaying. The user interface is intuitive and user-friendly, and the game offers a wide range of customization options for avatars, environments, and objects. The community in ChilloutVR is known for being welcoming, friendly, and supportive, making it an attractive alternative for those who are looking for a more relaxed and enjoyable virtual reality experience. It's unfortunate that the VRChat community has become increasingly toxic, but it's reassuring to see that alternative platforms like ChilloutVR exist where people can connect and enjoy virtual reality experiences without encountering negative behavior. It's also worth noting that legal issues have impacted some virtual reality communities, such as Neos VR, which highlights the importance of having a diverse range of virtual reality environments and platforms available to users. Overall, as virtual reality technology continues to evolve and become more accessible, it's important to foster positive and inclusive communities that prioritize respect and empathy for others.

137198841.review:
It's been almost a year since EAC dropped in VRChat.
This has been my exclusive social VR platform.
If VRChat ever went back to the way it was, I don't think I'd go back.

Since EAC, the servers have improved substantially in terms of stability. Though still not perfect, it continues to chug along at a steady pace.
The community here is tight. It has a small-town feel. You will see many of the same faces on a daily basis, but those are friendly faces.
If you come to cause trouble or be a nuisance, the community won't let you. Crashers are very few and far between due to the server detecting strange behavior and reporting it to moderation automatically.
Avatar ripping is protected against due to multiple obfuscation methods.
More features are always in the works. Scripting, real game modes, etc, are all planned.

The prop system is a big feature here. Rather than affixing all your toys and gadgets on your avatar, bloating it, you can upload them separately as a prop, so every one of your avatars can use it or others.
There are even props that you can use to extend the world you are in by building inside it. Want your own private area in a world? Use props and make it.
It keeps loading times down and functionality high.

The biggest deal, I would say, that here in CVR... public lobbies aren't cancer.

Give it a try. You don't have to choose to stay on one platform, but it is a different enough experience to warrant at least one night.

136630757.review:
I absolutely love this platform and I have a lot of passion for it. I enjoy the township feel in the stage this community of CVR is in right now. Everyone knows everyone, almost every user is some type of a creator. I love that there is a good resource of people wanting to help make stuff!

The performance here is amazing, I can be in a world with 30 people in good avatars and still have 90 frames. The current CCK is pretty robust, and it is fairly easy to port over avatars and or implement your own stuff. The current pipeline for new stuff like scripting is very exciting for me. Another thing to note I generally feel safer in Chilloutvr, I can go into public worlds without the fear of being crashed or my system being compromised. All user content, avatars, worlds, and props are encrypted. Stuff you made and upload won't be stolen.

Also props, in-game objects can be anything. You can legit make anything you want and add it to the game. It is the thing that is beyond amazing and cool about this social sandbox game. There is a nice in-depth tagging system to find what you're looking for. Plus you can tailor your experience to what you want with an avatar and props. Don't like flashing lights and loud noises? You can disable that and not deal with those things, it is a very smart feature that improves a lot of users' quality of life. It is very much GMOD in spirit and I think a lot of people feel right at home here.

The Developers and moderators are really going above and beyond for this platform. It is really nice seeing them playing their own game and interacting with their communities. They are very open to feature requests and other things the community wants in general. I am beyond happy that mods are a thing and are very supported by the developers. I get so happy and enjoy seeing new users coming onto this platform.

135125737.review:
I shall preface this review by saying no ChilloutVR is not a replacement for the other game, It never was meant to be that. Its more akin to Garry's Mod (GMod) over anything else. From the systems currently implemented and to the ones on the drawing board, ChilloutVR (CVR) at this moment in time has that sporadic chaotic energy that some [b] Older [/b] GMod fans would appreciate.

   As someone with mild social anxiety [spoiler] and fairly weak social skills [/spoiler] the one thing that surprised me the most was the community. [spoiler] I may get a bit emotional here, please bear with me [/Spoiler] Genuinely my heart goes out to the users that populate the rather few public lobbies at any given time, they honestly have to be some of the most brilliant and most passionate minds in the VR-Scape. A great number of them you'll find are constantly working on something in the background while they are in game, constantly trying to push the boundary of whats achievable in such a platform. Yet they are usually willing to stop for a moment and listen, whether it's to help exchange technical advice or to simply be an open ear. A lovely bunch they are so please don't ever be afraid to ask for help.

   I'm terms of administration this game probably has one of the most in-depth systems I've seen, Developers constantly roaming the lobbies, File encryption, Filter and Tag System's, A working partnership with a web security company, Hell I even saw the Founder of Alpha Blend Interactive (ABI) and CVR simply checking on how everyone was doing once [spoiler] which was both fucking awesome and nerve racking for someone like me [/spoiler] . Then there's the settings....soo many settings. They give you all the settings you could ever need to moderate your own experience within CVR, from content filtering settings to limiters that give you granular control over what is rendered on your end. The end goal of the developers from what I've heard is to protect users while giving next to full control over their experience while in game which is nutty if you ask me but deserves mad respect. All this without resorting to a half baked kernel based Anti-Cheat implementation. The Devs genuinely care for the users and the user experience and are usually open to answering questions and helping out whenever they can.

   Welp anyways I've been working at this review for nearly two hours now, there is still soo much I could talk about when it comes to the many features and systems that go on within this game but I'm getting a bit burnt out. 

   Please give this game a fair chance, don't just login for ten minuets and then dip, you'll just end up missing out on something incredible. Don't be afraid to ask for help, there are many users who are willing to lend out their time. Please Support the developers, the game is only made possible by donations/crowdfunding and developer free-time. Truly a Passion Project.

Probably the best Social VR game currently playable, the devs are good and the game runs well even in rather extreme Situations.

The good:
- Modding Support

- Very few to no annoying quest kiddies
- NO EAC

The bad:
- Currently a small playerbase
- Some issues persist in edge cases
- The usual Linux support issues that stem from Unity
- Not feature complete
- The UX is not the best yet, but being reworked if I understood things correctly

The ugly:

- Occasionally crashes, both hard crashing (in a lot of cases because I use mods) and soft crashing (ie losing connection for a bit and getting kicked out of an instance.)
- The small playerbase seems to be one of the main reasons why people don't seem willing to play it as much as VRC

134572762.review:
Close to hitting 800h here now, so time for a review!
Quick info about me: Programmer since 15years, worked with VR on and off since DK1 came out, work professionally as a Data Scientist. So I know my ways around Unity and quickly pick up new dev tools such as the CCK.

As a content creator:
I really like working with the CCK and it gives me tools to very quickly set things up in my worlds, such as drag & drop toggles, animator drivers, audio, basically anything where a user interacts with a world where no need for any advanced scripting or node graphs are needed.

Though, the lack of scripting is holding me back on some fronts, especially PvE combat worlds, but that will soon be released and with it I will release my own full PvE package for other creators to use to quickly create their own worlds.

Avatars are really easy and quick to set up, one can skip out a lot on making animators for toggles and instead use the CCK to create toggles with a quick Drag & Drop system. Very flexible in ways you can adjust your avatar, even Avatar Scaling work perfect and quick to set up.

Props are so nice to have, being able to carry any item over between avatars and be able to spawn them into any world as well. Seen full PvP tanks and fighters, starships, mini-worlds, weapons, games, event / community newspapers etc, it's crazy the different things people create with props.

Another big positive in my opinion as a content creator is the encryption of content, they do a really good job at protecting against ripping which shows they care about the creators. The Terms of Services are also very content creator friendly.

So far, I have created 6 worlds and 8 avatars during my time here since mid 2022.

As a player:
I really love the community and public instances here, a lot of friendly people that openly interact with others when approached, many helping each other out and just trying to make the platform really good. It makes me happy to see this and makes me want to spend time in publics.

Mature DLC is a very good addition to the platform, separating Violence / Suggestive / Nudity into a DLC to minimize the exposure of that towards minors but also for people who just don't want to see it. It keeps those things under check in a good way without banning them.

Something that surprised me was how much the devs engage with the player community in publics, been fun meeting several of them over time, to me it shows dedication towards their own platform.

There have been some bad people I have encountered during my time, but you can't avoid that anywhere on the internet. The moderation team is quick to handle issues, and you can just like devs see some moderator helping out to solve issues in instances and engage with players. Past two months I can't really remember running into any bad player.

Summary:
I really like the platform, many positives and few kinks. Really looking forward to the future and all the updates that are coming soon!

133809540.review:
CVR is an incredibly fun experience that deserves more attention. It hasn't been around as long as VRC but has made leaps and bounds in QoL improvements and persionalization features. The props feature is wild, you can still make avatar specific props but at the same time they've added the ability to make props you can load up with any avatar! Props like custom pens and keyboards and such are no longer avatar specific. you can add vehicles as props too.

As far as optimization goes it seems to be in a paradox of being better optemized than VRChat while also still being worse off, but with frequent updates and plans to bring the game to the latest versions of unity, they're expecting a jump in performance. 

The game isn't quest compatible which is unfortunate but it also means you don't have noisy children running around either. and with a smaller user base you'll find a tough time finding active instances. Playing last night at time of writing and there was quite literally only 2 active instances in the whole game, public at least. HOWEVER it was in one of those instances I found a group of regulars who really showed me the fun of ChilloutVR, I had to turn on my prop options but they showed me so much. I'll very much have to say CVR seems to have a very fun future and if it can get more players, it'll be a great time. Apparently they're bringing scripting into the game which will be an interesting thing there. 

There are major improvements that need to be made in its UI though, It's just as unorganized as VRChat's UI but not as appealing. it has room for improvement and as of now I wouldn't count it a replacement for VRC. but it's getting there. I'd recomend checking it out here and there, being an irregular player, maybe watching out for updates and checking outt he game after updates. you can very much be both a VRC and CVR player.

132830414.review: The community here is very close knit and kind, if you are new and join a public lobby most everyone will jump in to help show you around, VoyVivika is a big help so find him. The features are miles above the other game enough to where they steal them to try to compete, but they wont be able to with what the future beholds for this game. The prop system here is amazing, and is a must for any new players to try out, and there is a lack of avatar worlds due to the fact you can search up avatars in the main menu so there isnt much of a need. There are a few issues with lag on some people, which easily can be fixed in the settings menu, and the servers occasionally will time out if you are in the USA playing on an EU server or vice versa, but keep in mind the player base is small so theres no need for overkill servers at this point. it also can be confusing for new players to figure out controls in vr as there is no native keybindings other than using steamvr profiles to change the binds. There is a few quirks that takes some getting used to, but for a game thats only now pushing 2 years old at the time of writing, and never had a need to really push for quick updates with the 3 players it had average before people began moving here, its about what you would expect from any indie game in an infant stage. This game is definitely not bad at all though, theres much worse. the fact people can play on laptops from 2010 with little issue and still average over 60 fps is a big thing, and performance is expected only to improve. This game has a lot in store, and so much to come. 131233427.review:
well, I have over 400 hours in the game now so obviously I like the game. ChilloutVR aims to be a platform for world/game creation. they have a lot of aspirations for it and it will take some time to achieve. The one big feature they need to implement to catch up to their competitors is world scripting. Once world scripting is in place then you will be able to have game worlds just like VRC and NEOS have. If you have even the faintest interest then I recommend just trying it out. It's free and people are adding more content daily now. There are still quite times in the game, Monday-Wednesday are usually quite and most of the current players are either European or US based. There are many anti-crasher features that have been built into the game now and overall the stability is rather good. In VRC the video players cause me to crash but that doesn't happen in ChilloutVR. 

Overall I would give it 8/10. there's still issues to address but I like the community better. I also don't like having to create content in VR like NEOS wants you to.

129153986.review:
EDIT: The striked out text below is because of my own misunderstanding of the development of dynamic bones (as clarified by a lovely person in the replies!). Chillout uses a more current version of Dynamic Bones which is far better optimized than the one used in VRChat. I apologize for my flawed understanding ^.^'. Merry Christmas~!

I personally maintain that I love VRChat and that the game is a massively improved product after the EAC update. VRChat on an overall feature level is still at this point the superior product in my opinion. Unlike many people in the CVR community, I have no dirty feelings regarding VRC or its developers. Though the people with those dirty However I do see in ChilloutVR the bones of something that could surpass VRC.

ChilloutVR has its own charm. It is an immensely better optimized experience (getting double the FPS at higher people counts than VRC on similar worlds) and is an overall free-er experience. You can upload and insert your own props for example!

The first person I met on CVR showed me around and tossed me in a prop that teleported you 2 kilometers into the sky to show off a horror maze he made. We didn't even leave the world. Another person put down a prop that created a massive space battle at the edge of the skybox that was bad*** to look at.

[strike][i]However one of the primary issues I am wary of is the over-reliance on dynamic bones. Dynamic bones are a highly unoptimized technology not meant for the scale it was implemented in VRC and still is in CVR. For a long time there was a false rumor that VRC entirely ran on a single CPU thread because of how dynamic bones specifically are simulated.[/i][/strike] 

[strike]However I have been told that there are people working on a solution to this problem and I wish them all the luck in the world. If dynbones can be replaced with some comparable or superior in quality to physbones then this game will genuinely be a more stable experience then VRC in all respects.[/strike] Feature-parity would then make it a far superior experience overall.

ChilloutVR, from my experience thus far, has been a game with a respectful mature community willing to introduce the wonders of its experience and quirks to new users. It is overall far superior on performance than its aspirational competitor VRC is for most VR-ready hardware.

125859345.review:
I have played this game for almost 600 hours so i feel like its my right to post my review for this game in short and long:

Pros:
-Perfect for chilling out

-The community is very supportive or this game and most of the time will help new players out if asked

-Active development team that listens to the concerns of the many AND the few... (Larry included)

-Regular/frequent club hosting (for those that likes clubbing)

-VERY few people there are very wholehearted and genuine people

-over 50% of the community are furries or anime girls (if you like furries)

-Best security i've seen so far (no DDoS or hacking)

-Pretty good performance if you meet the system requirements

-Relaxed staff/moderation so you can be silly and mess around within reason

-Perfect for outcasts, misfits, or anyone who struggles with social interactions


Cons:
-Difficult development/staff team treatment if you try to work through the system with them; you most likely will get ghosted half way though or blocked by developers or the community guide

-No tutorial so you have to ask others how to do things

-Frequent crashes for people that have not met minimum requirements unless you remove most of the fun in the game like the video player and props

-HIGHLY nationalistic community so generally you would not be liked or get blocked if you have any gripes with this game or have any positive reservations for its competitors like Neos or VRChat (or if you try to delete your account)

-No active games nor general interest for it (so far);  Throughout my time there was only one never have i ever/Yes or no session played ever

-Lots.. and i mean lots... of furries (if you don't like furries)

-A lot of people here have social/emotional abnormalities when interacting with them so be careful unless you don't mind being blocked on a weekly basis. 


My Story:
This game I joined because VRC has some sort of EAC update which not only didn't sit well with me personally but also because the EAC update didn't solve any of the root problems VRC had. When i came to this game last October It had the same feel to VRC but..less people, less toxicity, new gadgets like props, a video player and people helped me understand the game mechanics and settings. What more could you ask for right? 

Well since my computer is half a decade old about 14/15 times i join a world with a video player and people are using it i would crash and have to start the application over again. I ask people if there was any way to solve the problem but for a good number of months all i received was "Seems like a skill issue" or "get a new computer"... thanks... It wasn't until about a month ago that someone told me that all i had to do was disable a file on my file explorer to not load the video player. That helped in letting me join my friends but it never game me the same experience that they can be laughing at a funny clip while I’m just watching a black screen. 

Without being able to watch movies and clubs not really being my thing the best thing i have left is trying to make conversation with everyone here. In general I want to say beforehand that I care about everyone in the community and want the best for the community itself. I will admit that i am not the best at that talent so when i try the next best thing of being silly as an ice breaker it was met with a wide range of different reactions. I've been hit, mocked, gas-lighted, teased, spat on, ignored, vote kicked, and blocked for the worst range and on the lighter side i have  been hugged, complimented, friend requested, given small talk,  moaned, and licked at. The least i can say would be that it is an 'interesting' community but it is up to perspective of what that means. For a majority of the time i experienced, unless you bring up something that they really love talking about you would be ignored. Without being able to talk to know conversation topics it is very difficult to have a genuine wholehearted conversation with someone. 

When i figured out there was nothing really left i can do with the game i wanted to delete my account (note this was before April 2023). When i went to ask my community guide on how to delete my account since i did not see any icon on the ABI page he immediately went on the defensive and without any clear answer he blocked me. I asked the legend member there for advice and was told to check out the ABI discord. When i went to the ABI discord I noticed that you cannot send a ticket to get your account deleted. Instead you have to send an email to the dev team to say that you want your account deleted. I went to a dev member to know what is the process to delete your account and about 2 hours later of interacting with the dev team i was given an impossible request to send a email of my abi (which was deleted before and i replaced), a transaction receipt (which requires you to pay money to obtain) and a file code of something to verify its you. I got the new email i believe and with the help of a dev i found the file code and sent it back only to get ghosted and when i confronted about it i was given the work around that "there wasn't enough". Thus ended my ability to delete my account without paying money (any pressing of the issue got me blocked by a dev) until this month it made the whole process way easier.

In summary, this game is the closest to a successful virtual reality platform to me and that despite the problems i have encountered by the community or dev team, I do wish that this game becomes way larger than it is now as it truly deserves!


UPDATE (9/16/23):

This developments of the game on the side of functionality have elevated from my last posting but the community as a whole has taken the abyssal drop i never expected. The entire community is filled with those whom are not mentally secure to follow a normal conversation with most likely because there is no pillar of normalcy that hasn't been desecrated. I can only list a handful of people that are normal in a sense but the rest will spark drama because it gets them off basically. The worst part as someone who likes the game itself is that most of the negative reviews of the game are correct! There is no tutorial, the account creation is way more tedious, there is barely anyone who is on public worlds, the toxicity has increased in general to the point of cannibalizing its own veterans, and worst of all the idea of this community being nothing more than a hate group of VRChat is ABSOLUTELY TRUE. 

I debated with myself multiple times if i should involve myself with trying to separate the idea of the game from being nothing more than a shadow of VRC or not but the point is that the community would be more than happy to outcast or scapegoat you to make them feel better as they sink before blaming another. Last time i tried it for deleting my own account i was successful in the end but the community already has outcast me as just a troublemaker.

I do not know if i should try or not but i know for certain that the ship cvr stands on will rot and die from the inside out if i just watch from the sidelines. Its already started and is a matter of time before noone exists there anymore or the rest just stick to private worlds.

122423846.review:
Granted that VRChat has ruined itself beyond its prior state by adding EAC, I have to recommend ChilloutVR as an alternative. ChilloutVR has surprisingly fewer active world instances compared to VRChat. However, it does have several issues - I've listed playability issues first.

Desktop play specs: Debian 11 bullseye, AMD Ryzen 7 5800X 8-Core (16 threads), AMD RX 580 8GB, 32 GB DDR4

The microphone voice activity doesn't seem to be adjustable - my mic is practically always on (and no, I don't have that option enabled). Sometimes the game stutters or freezes for brief or extended periods of time.

Strangely, setting AA to off results in increased CPU usage (~300%) while still managing good framerates (around 144 FPS) under ideal conditions, whereas setting it to 4x (the default) results in reduced CPU usage (~90%) but a measly 15-30 FPS.

As in VRChat, other players' avatars are a severe hindrance to performance. It's practically impossible to fine-tune the advanced safety settings when you don't have any data on how many polys, etc. a particular player's avatar has. This makes it very difficult to optimize performance at all. Additionally, clicking and dragging on numerical slider settings does not offer precision. It would be useful to be able to input a number, click a +/- button, or shift+scroll on a setting to adjust its value by some setting-respective multiple.

Notably, the "Reset Settings" button in the menu does not work at all. I expected the button to reset the settings for the currently open menu, but nothing happens. It would be useful to be able to see what the default setting are. Tooltips could come in handy, too. I couldn't quickly locate an obvious configuration file, so I later just reinstalled the game to reset all of the settings and start from scratch.

Ok so its been quite a while since i made this review and just wanna say a few extra things just to let anyone who may be seeing this what has changed so far. i haven't played a lot but that's mostly because i have been playing a lot of other games since i first started playing this. although i did get online recently and a bit has changed since this review.

for one the game has since gotten a lot more optimized, no more lagging for 5 minutes strait while all the avatars load in. the devs have also added a few features to the game to make modding easier, most notably a mod network which allows you to make a mod that can send and receive events so you can make mods that sync between other players with said mod. the scripting still has yet to come out yet but from what I've heard they are actively working on it now, it might still be a while before it comes out but when it does the amount of thing you can make will skyrocket even higher than it already is.

overall this game has gotten so much better than it already was and is still getting better every update.

121545685.review:
while it is true that this game is still young in its development, this has been one of the most refreshing vr social platform experiences for me. the amount of technical features this game has implemented and will support over time is quite literally perfect for my play style. the developers themselves have proven to be excellent with user feedback and communication, which is very promising, and not to mention, very admirable!

only time will tell for the future of this platform, as both the community and the on-going support for the game are, while ambitious, still very small and have a lot of ground to cover. i think one of the biggest issues right now is the game's public perception. on the surface, this game does not accurately reflect the end goals that the developers wish to achieve and, i hate to say it, but it makes it only come off as only a vrchat clone to the public eye. to make things worse, the patreon page for chilloutvr hasn't made a post in 2 years and does not provide any enticing subscription incentive aside from supporting the developers, and the steam page is more than outdated and generally cruddy.

lastly, i'd like to mention that i feel as if most of the criticism that this game receives (such as the game having little community content / small player numbers, or people outright suggesting users to not play chilloutvr and play vrchat until the game improves) is unfair and counter-intuitive. it is true that there is much work to be done developer-wise, but i highly encourage everyone to not blame the game for problems it alone cannot solve; a plant cannot grow without plenty of water. the only way this game can improve is by giving it the community support it needs, not by telling others to come back later. 

[i]TL;DR: this game is by no means perfect, but if you're new to CVR, please consider giving this game a genuine shot! there is a lot to love about it, and with everyone's support, the experience will only get better from here.[/i]

121539010.review:
[h1] Chillout has much more to prove to itself than what ive witnessed from a month on this platform. [/h1]


Seeing how this game was made out of spite against VRC, and seeing how jank the SDK is compared to VRC, as an avatar creator, Im saying no to this platform. Ive spent countless times trying to upload an avatar to the platform only for it to just never appear whenever it uploads and I try to change it. 

Their discord community is nowhere near helpful either, as my requests either get ignored or i get a blunt response, "just wait." 

As a friend of mine once said about the feud between VRC and CVR... 

[i] "Your social media platform needs people.
That's because people also make culture.

Yeah, sure for a regular video game you can hop to a clone most of the times, but hoping between Vrchat to another title
is like hoping from discord to facebook. 
Functionally they're very similar, but things that would fly on discord would get you canceled on facebook or vice versa.

I think what most people forget is that Vrchat isn't a game in the traditional sense, it's a social media platform.' [/i]

The years and years of culture made on VRChat can't light a candle to the infancy of what CVR offers. Its so far ahead of the competition that it practically has no competiton. Why do away with it? It was hard enough for me to make the inner circle of friends i made on VRC. I realized I was being immature over the loss of mods when I started playing without mods to start with. Its a lose/lose situation, but my clouded judgement would have made my experience even less enjoyable,

[b] This is in no way, shape or form of me defending VRC for its eradication of mods via EAC, [/b] but You'd expect better from alternatives who want to quickly jump ship and upload their content without issue, as well as trying to find worlds to interact with people easily, but personally, I havent been able to find that comfort here, despite what others around me are saying.

As it stands, I will be keeping my business with VRChat, as i dont want to give up the many obligations i have to friends and family on that platform, though with caution. And as for this platform, I havent been able to Chillout.

A game where the devs actually listen to the community and care. Encrypted uploaded content so content creators dont have to worry about their content being ripped. Implemented anti crash features due to which i have not yet faced any crashes in the game. Allow mods which are whitelisted by the team and are not malicious. A much better and non toxic community.
Due to a sudden influx of players, the priorities of the dev team shifted from reworking UI and other features to implementing anti crash features and reworking the entire backend to be able to support the influx of players alongwith providing security against ddosers. 

Cons do include the current playerbase being low, having to relearn a new sdk (cck in the case of cvr) to create content on unity or port from another game however this isnt as much of an issue if you arent lazy and lack of content however with several creators shifting to cvr, there has been a steady rise in that. 
Albeit none of these cons affect me as much as the game itself has been pretty laidback and fun but some players may find these to be reason enough not to play. 

P.s: NO EAC :v

121197309.review:
WARNING! This is a LONG review! There is a simple TLDR paragraph below! 
I want to preference this review by saying that CVR is everything i wanted in a VR game. The devs care, the small community is caring, and the recent fiasco with VRC has pushed alot of people away and into CVR's new user base to find a new home where their work matters. But unfortunately I must also go over some fundamental flaws that I find with the game's community that bleeds over into the game as well as why the current player base is falling off so quickly as of writing this review. 
    To start off, so far alot of things have been addressed with this game. Server stability? Check. Exploiters and rippers? Encrypted uploads and daily patches to make malicious client code monkey's work their asses off? Check. Updates to the CCK (this games version of the unity SDK) to make it more intuitive? Check. 
    The ONLY problem now is the fact that new comers CANNOT bring over content from VRchat to this game. If VRC SDK to CCK converters were more practical then the barrier of entry for taking someone's payed for content and porting it over would be astronomically easier for the average Joe. As is, however, due to lack of  *community* (notice i said community and not DEV) content the current SDK to CCK converter we have is subpar. (As these converters are made by *community* modders to make converting avatars to a different creator engine a bit easier.) Sometimes it doesn't bring over the vesimies properly. Sometimes it f*cks up animations/gestures.

NOTE! If these converters f*ck up an animation/ vesimie (in fact anything to deal with animations/using the unity animator at all.) then the average Joe is f*cked. You can look at yourself either getting into unity creating and trouble shooting and taking up your general time to try and figure out why your avatar won't work or you can go back to the game where your favorites are and where the fbx files you own actually work. (spoiler alert, most people are going to pick the option of least resistance.)
    Most people who buy avatars usually only buy them as is, then get someone to work on them for a commission fee. These people don't understand how Unity works, nor want to go through the troubleshooting problems of making their previous avatar work on another game's SDK. 
    Unfortunately, the bleeding of CVR's relevance is also compounded on the fact that learning the CCK is out of the question at the moment for the new user. The new user needs to start with VRC's SDK to learn the fundamentals before coming over to the CCK (unless of course, they have a friend). The reason why that is, is because there is BARELY ANY recorded/written documentation, tutorials, or straight up videos on how to work the CCK. There was a new wave of documentation on this games forums and discord channel, but the forums only surged with tutorials on how to convert a VRC avatar to a CVR avatar and how to do some of the basics of the CCK editor regarding AAS (Advanced Avatar Settings). Hell, the forum tutorial post only goes over the most fundamental basics on how to get your avatar working from the VRC SDK. Visimies f*cked? too bad, gestures f*cked? go lurk in the official discord channel or beg for help every day. I am being serious when I say barely anyone wants to write or document the CVR CCK animator due to "how much time and effort it would take to explain everything." Which is fair. Nobody is obligated to waste their time creating this sort of content and helping newbies out. But because nobody wants to do this for what is arguably ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT UNITY TOOLS TO LEARN, and barely anyone has, this game is HEAVILY suffering from it due to newbies  being unable to read up on the non existent written/video tutorials to help troubleshoot themselves.
    Suddenly over 20k people are clamoring for your new service trying to move to your new game but unfortunately, the new game doesn't support their avatar(s) or something broke on it requiring them to now take potentially weeks upon weeks to fix it. People aren't willing to lose everything they owned and payed for to support a new IP. People also aren't willing to learn 3 different software programs, and take weeks working with them just to make their avatars work. It just isn't happening. People were MOVING from VRC, thus trying to bring their avatars they payed for with them.  Hell, I myself have tried CVR but couldn't get my avatars I payed for to work even after reading all the forum posts and lurking in the official discord so i simply went back to VRC. (Now granted I have been taking the hard road, and have been learning Unity, substance3DPainter, and Blender, but until I get confident in those enough and learn how they work fundamentally I'm not touching the CCK with a 10ft pole until some dev backed content regarding how specifically the animator and vesimies works differently compared to the SDK comes out, or community made tutorials become more common place then the dried up wasteland of content we have now.) 
    The point of the above is to state that  if you want to port your avatar from VRC to Chillout VR you need to know how blender, substance3Dpainter, and Unity work. (aka you know them well enough you probably sell clothing assets, can sculpt in blender reliably,  and or take basic commissions every now and then.) If you don't care for learning this stuff then good luck porting ANYTHING from VRC to CVR. Unless you have a friend who is willing to do it for you, you're sunk in the water without any alternative. 
    And none of this is the developers fault. This is all simply a byproduct of just exactly how small CVR was until this massive wave of players overswept them. Now the waves are receding and the devs and community are finding out that they hadn't prepared anything to keep player's attention and avatars over on this game in case of this happening. 
    Due to the above mentioned reasons on why players are leaving, the only people staying are content creators. Which is fine. This game needs them. But alot of content creators go to where the people are to make friends, and share their content. It won't be likely that they stay here unless its to support each other which would be the ideal outcome. With a web of interconnected content developers supporting each other, they'll be able to create things for themselves and others, tutorials, assets, mods, props, worlds, and much much more to slowly but surely make it easier and convenient to allow new comers to more easily port over their avatars or even help them create one themselves. 

TL:DR The lack of a community, made CVR unprepared for the massive influx of people that came in. Due to the non existant content, tutorials, servers, and other community made (and some dev) content, people could not easily move over from VRC to CVR due to how hard it was to port their avatars. Most people aren't going to just drop everything to move and support a new IP. There has to be compromise. They had already made the move even if their friends weren't going, they weren't going to make the move, lose their friends, AND lose their avatars too. 
    I'll end this review off with this. I'm learning all these things because when someone said it would be too much work to teach us newcomers the CCK animator I got pissed. I want to support this game. I DON't want to support VRC. I don't want to support a company that is backed by Eastern Investors who are so out of touch with their  GENERAL community. I want a game that has competent devs running the helm. Who know what it will take to make their game, and I want to be a part of something new to allow this platform to take off. I will learn Unity on VRC just so I can hop into the CCK, play around with it and then hopefully learn it to the point I can document the animator. It will take time, but, hopefully it will be worth it once I either complete my journey, or someone else does it.

121071906.review:
Still has a lot of UI/UX and features to work on, but already a really solid SocialVR platform.
Content workflow is a lot more beginner friendly thanks to the CCK's automation tools for advanced toggles, there's a proper, working tagging system for R-18 content (as well as many other filterable options), and the ToS is permissive towards modding, so say hello to better accessibility and jank-free device integrations!
And props! No longer do we need special avatars to have a spontaneous swordfight, and you can bring your own car to races! You can also share your content with specific friends rather than publishing it fully, truly filling all the major gaps it's major competitor has left open for many, many years at this point!
I can't wait to see what the future holds for CVR, from both developers and community!

So my hours are rather low in this game but I do believe it deserves a positive review.
CVR is a game with a lot of potential, right now it is behind in terms of basic tech, but what it excels at is the developers and attitude towards the community.
Updates are rolling in constantly, playability had already gone up massively in less than a month with very fresh developers.
UI does feel older but is really quick to understand, customisation is there, isn't hard for a new person to grasp how to play, and for anyone wanting to get stuck in and really get some customisation with mods the modding community is growing and healthy (and is allowed and endorsed by the dev team).

So my closing thoughts, the game as of right now is playable with a growing community, but needs time to grow to a true large vr experience, and with the healthy patreon numbers it already has, it's only a matter of time before it grows to something truly fantastic.

Give this game a chance!

[b]Update 250 hours:[/b]
There are props, a better community, next to no kids, a better UI, devs constantly working on the game, better IK for fullbody, faster avatar/world upload times, no features hidden behind paywalls, better separation of adult content, little to no mirror dwellers, and you can even have mods!
This game is the escape from VRChat you've always wanted. You jump on now or wait till everyone else drags you here anyways. This game will grow with time and we need people to create for this platform. Be the person that starts something amazing :3

[b]Update 500 hours:[/b]
Public props are now a thing. Many people see them as the main reason to play the game and I see why. The versatility of certain things like spawning in a video player, flashlight, or even something funny can leave you with hundreds of hours of content and laughs. This game Isn't 100% yet but when it hits that sweet spot it's gonna be amazing.

[b]Update 750 hours:[/b]
Less people are on consistently and many have made their way to other games. In that same regard more people have come around and found this game to be their new main VR platform. Public props have made the experience fun to look through pages of public props that anyone can use. People are genuinely nice and looking for conversation. To top it all off the experimental mode with it's new features are a great view on what's to come.

120694235.review:
For a Social VR Platform that is only a couple years old,  it is impressive how far they've come, and how quickly they responded to the recent influx of new players. While the game is still in need of many features, the impression I have had from the dev team and the game so far makes me very optimistic towards this game's future.

It already has many QoL features, such as:
A proper content tagging system for avatars, worlds, and props that the user can filter
A prop system
A few different IK settings
Advanced safety settings
Positive attitude towards mods
Easy to use and feature-full Content Creation Kit
Quick transitioning between worlds
And much more I cannot be bothered to sit here and spend ages listing off.

The dev team is willing to bite the bullet in order to improve their game sooner, rather than leaving things broken for months like some other Social VR platforms; and example of this being their recent decision to shut down the servers so they could implement fixes and new back-end server software so they could provide their players with a more stable experience once they got the servers back up; which from my experience has worked wonders.

The bottom line is Chillout VR is already a good experience for it's age, and has a team of good-intentioned and smart developers behind it that treat their growing community well.

If you want to move over to Chillout VR from another Social VR platform, but are afraid to because it's not where your friends are my advice is to move over anyways; by moving over to CVR you give your friends a reason to move over too.

120692242.review:
I play these sandbox games for the content creation functionality. I love the challenges presented and the tools given to me to solve these problems. From simple things like an avatar toggle to straight up game logic in a shader, you can do a whole lot here in terms of content creation. (avatars, props, worlds, mods, and soon serverside scripting!~)

I feel there is a lot of promise in this platform and that it fits my ideals in what I want from a user content driven platform very well. Developers are very straight up and human, and the community is very approachable with little toxicity.

I do obviously need to state I am a VRChat convert... a review here isn't fair without it. But I do want to say I did try this game two years ago (2020~) and already wanted to switch.
Really wish I stuck around back then...
https://youtu.be/k4R4KcuAtWI


There is plenty I can say to pick apart this game in its current state. Obviously something like this isn't going to meet everyones ideals right off the bat, but the influx of users and new developers give so much promise for the future yet to come. (and all the feedback :3)

This game alone has given me the ability and reason to dive much much deeper into advanced scripting, modding, and Unity creation than I normally would have elsewhere- and for that I am thankful.

----
rant bit after playing almost 3k hours:
----


We need better creator tools and UI before any sort of push for more players. No one will want to move if the platform in general seems like a downgrade from what they are used to.

ChilloutVR also needs to sort out their outward appearance as a brand. They have no landing page for new users to learn about the platform, no good documentation for their creator tools, their Twitter status page hasn't even been touched in 2 years, the Twitter tags are mainly VRChat p*rn, TOS written in broken English and contradicting itself in places, and their press kit page is just broken.

The platform entirely needs a major cleanup to its outside image if we are to attract new players. We also need better tools and proper UI to keep those players longer than an hour.

----
end
----

This platform has a ton of potential but really needs to work on its outside image & tooling for creators. While I recommend this game for those like me, who really value an open sandbox to do anything in, i would not recommend this game for those who play VR casually or just want something stable to create for.

Honestly there isn't much benifit creating stuff here. Nothing new is offered or gamechanging from competing platforms- hell, its a major downgrade. Hopefully that all changes in CCK4.

120684189.review:
Absolutely amazing social VR game. Actively encourages modding and has a very nice community. 

Had a bumpy few weeks whenever an influx of VRChat players all moved over after VRChat's 'Security Update' hit where the servers were so overloaded that noone could register on Chillout but all the server issues seem to have cleared up now.

Not to mention it has insane performance boost compared to VRChat. No more 40 FPS at all times and actually some decent FPS (Check out The Black Cat and compare it to VRChat's performance in the same world)

Even some of the MelonLoader developers now work on the ABI team (and a few big mod creators) which would allow for more QOL features a lot faster.

They've also added actual features that have been missing in VRChat since the start

* [b]BundleVerifier[/b] (Anti-crasher)
* [b]AdvancedSafety[/b] (Removes broken/invalid avatars and objects to prevent crashes)
* [b]True Shader AntiCrash[/b]

I'm not saying this game is perfect as it does have some problems
For instance the UI can be a bit weird sometimes and a little daunting for players starting out.
There are talks of a UI overhaul which may replace the CoHTML UI
Lack of visual/haptic feedback when pressing buttons but that could also be fixed in the UI overhaul

120604900.review:
Rough around the edges but a pretty good social VR game. In my opinion it has a better foundation than VRChat, though it's behind in development. There are a few things that stand out to me over VRChat, though. One is the lack of loading screens when transitioning between worlds. It feels really good and more seamless than world hopping in VRC.
I also find myself getting more frames in Chillout VR than I ever do in VRChat. In simple worlds with friends, even with dynamic bones I get 100-120 FPS, I honestly forget how smooth high FPS felt. It makes the game feel more immersive.

It also has a lot of curation tools that are absent from VRChat, the safety settings are more robust, though there isn't a ranking system like VRC. There's an avatar search, which is very nice for getting started in the game without hours of world hopping looking at public avatars. 

The game also allows you to make and share props, which is really cool. Someone spawned a car and someone else was able to drive it. Someone also gave me a nerf gun I could fire at people. 

Currently, the IK system and the UI are pretty complicated, and can feel pretty jarring at first. Though the devs have mentioned they are working on reworking it. 

The creators also stated they're currently reaching out to mod creators to help iron out some of the rough spots in their game currently, so expect third party fixes to things like UI and Fullbody tracking. 

There's usually people around to chat to, and I haven't had any issues with connectivity lately so it seems like that's been sorted out. It really just feels like very early VRChat, event he community. Everyone seems pretty eager to meet randoms right now, so I think it's a very good place to jump in.

As I am making this review, I have migrated from a certain other VR social platform that isn't listening to its own user base and is making every possible wrong decision.

This one, ChilloutVR, is still VERY small and still slowly growing, and is recently suffering from DDOS attacks, and a sudden huge amount of new players and accounts. So, the developers are working on beefing up the servers and welcoming everyone. Don't let the current instability of the game discourage you from giving it a try when it'll become more stable.

I cannot wait for more creators to join.

Also, this platform supports/allows the following:
- Groups (To make one, you need the premium version but it is a one time purchase, so it is very worth it!)
- Avatar making/uploading
- World making/uploading
- Client-Sided Modding, as long as it isn't against the TOS

Pros:
Unlike VRC they encourage modding and actually care about the community
Very good communication on their discord as to what they're currently working on
The camera is awesome, better than any other vr camera I've used (sounds small but use it and you'll most likely fall in love 
    with it like I did).
Uploading avatars is simpler than VRC

Cons:
I have to admit that right now their servers are bit of a dumpster fire, they are working to fix them but yeah rn not great.
The number of worlds is a lot smaller than VRC but it IS getting a lot better as more and more are ported over
Avatars use a much older physics system that VRC just moved away from and it is definitively worse.
Lower player numbers, meaning there are less people here and less people to meet
No quest compatibility, not a problem for me but might be an issue for others.

EDIT: The servers have been fixed and are now much more stable and reliable unlike they were shortly after release.

In all the most important thing for me is that they actually care about their community unlike VRC (and are actually updating the game unlike NEOS which hasn't gotten an update in 6 months) I highly recommend this over VRC for that fact alone but I get that some of the cons I listed are a dealbreaker for some, particularly the lower players since it means your friends probably aren't here (if you're moving from VRC) I don't hold that against you but at least take a look and try Chillout for yourself.

120184527.review:
Server issues aside (which hopefully should be fixed in the next few hours), ChilloutVR has the vibe of old VRChat, but with developers who won't lie to your face.

This game shows a lot of promise, and the developers foster a much more positive environment than the VRChat devs. They actively work with modders instead of pretending like they're all criminals, and build a system around NSFW content instead of trying to ban it from the platform to appease investors. The moderators also actually moderate the platform, unlike in VRChat, so it's a much safer and less toxic place to be. The developers also actively engage with users on Discord and in-game, which is always nice to see.

The CCK is a lot easier to work with for avatars than VRChat's nightmarish SDK, and has some nice features (like an actual in-game color picker for parameters, which I didn't even realize I needed in life). The worlds side of things is pretty much on par with VRChat's SDK2, with a few extra niceties. I also appreciate the prop system and the actual proper content sharing system, which allows you to upload an avatar to your account and share it directly with friends (or clients if you're doing avatar commissions).

This is a tiny thing, but the camera is also really neat. It has a cute little drone mode that lets you get some nice shots of worlds and stuff, and it has a (slightly janky right now) orbit mode, which you can use to get some pretty cool shots. My only critiques there are that the orbit mode behavior isn't super clear (it orbits the camera, not the player) and the focus mode could really use a point autofocus option.

In general, CVR shows a lot of potential, and it seems to be doing everything right that VRChat kept doing wrong. They don't rely on investor money that stifles creativity and puts profits over people. We need more devs like this in the VR space.

120138869.review:
For all its flaws, it's an app showing great potential.

ChilloutVR has seemed to be a social application that flew under the radar of most people since it's been out. I feel the incredibly small development team behind it also felt that, and are currently feeling it now that the spotlight shining much more brightly in their direction. While it's still very much a Work In Progress, I feel it has a lot to bring to the table in terms of how a VR Social Experience should be run.

For one, filtering accessible content through an age rating system is a great thing. Allowing kids and adults to have their own separate spaces can only be a good thing, as older games like Second Life has proven.

A proper inventory system, while still in the works, could open the door for more versatile avatar customization in game.

Actual modding capabilities, with the devs being in discussion with the creators of popular mods can only lead to good things, via better integration, while filtering out anything that could be malicious.

Overall, I see great things in store for ChilloutVR, and I'm going to be watching it very carefully.

I'm gonna be brutally honest here.
Compared to VRChat, this is not a great experience.
The UI is very unpleasant to use, the networking can be pretty unstable, there's barely any worlds to explore, and there's usually only a few populated lobbies at any one time.
If you don't care about the way VRChat is managed, and how VRChat Inc treats their community, then right now ChilloutVR doesn't have much appeal.
Key word being [b]now.[/b]
ChilloutVR has been quite dead for a year or so, and it's still waking up from that.
But the smell of opportunity is ripe in the air, and this could become something truly great.
I have faith that the devs can handle their side of things - fixing up the UI, optimizing the client, stabilizing the network, etc.
As for worlds, avatars, and people?
That's up to us, the community.
So upload an avatar, build a world, tell a friend!
Keep that dream alive!
