120066878.review:
I, as many others have come here after the great EACpocalypse of vrchat, so a fair bit of this will be comparing to that.. within reason of course 

Lets start with some positives
Security:
one of the biggest and in my opinion important differences between vrc and cvr is that security issues are not just simply ignored
vrchat has been suffering a crashing and malicious modding problem since pretty much the early days
often a lot of these issues arent fixed for months, if at all, crashing remains practically unaddressed to this day
CVR on the other hand implemented what is the anticrash mods we used to have in VRC, this was done together with previous modders, of which a fair few are part of CVRs team now
Security issues like the funny floor drop that happened during the early wave was fixed within a day or 2, for example
Other issues are fixed before they become a problem thats widely abused to begin with

As a side effect of this its actually much rarer to have any malicious activity at all, ironically you can just leave the avatar anticrash features disabled, since their simple existence is deterrent enough (the smaller playerbase may also be a part of why malicious people dont bother, but more about that later)

The IK (how your body moves, very important for full body users):
In the initial wave, CVR was using a fairly old and janky version of iktweaks, yes that is the mod that existed for vrchat, but built in
This has since been upgraded and, for the most part, is much closer to what the mod was later on
The clear advantages here are that you can actually adjust your IK settings to match you and your avatar, something vrchat simply refuses to do as they try to go for a one size fits all solution, resulting in a one size fits a specific kind of rig only mess
Other things that make it better are its update rate, which means that remotely it will update a lot faster than vrchats very low and extremely interpolated and smoothed mess, issues like your body vibrating if you dare to turn your head are also nowhere to be found

Modding:
CVR allows non malicious modding, which stands in stark contrast to vrchat that only had tolerated and now actively destroyed it (despite it only having killed wholesome modding and malicious modding being just as rampant as before)
if you are familiar with the old VRC Modding group, it essentially just turned into the ChilloutVR modding group
You can find lots of neat features and fixes that the CVR team wasnt able to implement yet for various reasons (like priority, time)

Props:
You can spawn props, anytime, anywhere*
*If the map isnt set to disallow this, the absolute vast majority of maps will allow it however
Props can be a fun toy to mess around with, spawning avatar independent things that you can set to do plenty of similar things as you would with an avatar, as a creator
Props can be interacted with by you and other people

Searching:
The game has a built in avatar, prop and as expected world search
You can find this at the bottom middle of the main (the big not attached to your hand) menu, the search is universal for all, simply put in what you wanna search for, then on the left side you can view the results for avatars, props, worlds and users
sadly this is limited to 30 in each

NSFW Content:
This is allowed by the game, assuming your content is tagged appropriately
You need the free mature content dlc to enable seeing NSFW tagged content, sadly its unobtainable in some countries like germany
NSFW being allowed however does NOT mean you can freely be NSFW
You are still not allowed to participate in NSFW activity outside of private instances, or run around naked
You are however covered, if tagged appropriately, by accidental wardrobe malfunctions, or your avatar having detailed naughty bit textures as long as you are wearing clothes over it

The content filter:
Theres a pretty decent list of tags content can be tagged with
You can choose to not see certain types of content by simply disabling it in the content filter settings
Some of these will block the avatar entirely, others will just remove things like particles
Avatar creators have the ability to tag specific parts of their avatar that will then just get removed instead of the entire avatar

Now for some bad things
The overall feeling of "jank" and lack of polish:
If you have already tried CVR or are about to, you may notice how the interface looks very placeholdery
That is because it essentially is, you can find some unimplemented features here, or settings that simply dont do anything
The look is definitely in dire need of an upgrade
As well as trying to click on a checkbox often just launching you to the top or bottom of the page due to a lack of click to drag delay
However saying all this, this is something that is on the list of "will be changed", a new menu will be there eventually

Avatar loading performance:
Avatars will cause a fair bit of stutter when they load in, much more than you may be used to from vrchat

Lack of proper prop moderation:
You cant block a specific prop, or an authors props, only block someone from spawning any props

And now for the elephant.. or ant? in the room
The size of the playerbase:
A lot of people will simply dismiss the game due to its pretty small size, which yes, can be a problem depending on how you wish to play this type of game
If you want to just hop on, play some game worlds, or find some quick action of other types of activities, this may not be the ideal place for you
On the plus side, the smaller playerbase does mean that bad actors are generally quickly filtered out, its also a much more relaxed experience
I recommend checking this game out during its peak times, which would be starting at 20:00 GMT (convert to your local timezone yourself)


To close this off with
A lot of developer effort is currently going into upgrading from unity 2019 to 2022, which will bring performance improvements, much easier support for standalone vr headsets (quest and pico version will be coming)
However this means that other things are pushed back, which is reasonable enough as doing it right before such a massive upgrade would be a lot of wasted effort

Would i recommend checking out CVR?
Absolutely, you lose nothing but a bit of your time, its free, other than the unlock dlc which is very fairly priced and only really relevant if you wish to create lots of content, as a normal user it doesnt actually offer anything you need

Try not to be too discouraged by the issues i listed above like the unpolished feel, there is good stuff to be found underneath
You also dont have to pick between CVR or VRC, this is not a permanent choice, its a game, do what you want, play what you want whenever you want, so theres no issue with playing both

The list above is by no means a complete list of positives, or even downsides, it simply was what i could think of at this moment

In fact CVR is working with the modding community which it great and I love to see people work together. I also ran some tests between CVR and VRC.

FPS
VRC before EAC: 144 FPS home world
VRC EAC: 73FPS home world
CVR: 144 FPS home world

Launch times
VRC before EAC: 12 seconds
VRC EAC: 53 seconds
CVR: 3 seconds to splash screen

Jitter/Lag (Frame Drops, Lag, Crashing, ect..)
VRC before EAC: Moderate
VRC EAC: High
CVR: Low

This game also allows mature content that you can choose to see or not and there is not subscription for a premium account. I would like to see where this goes and hope this game takes off. You guys got this.

119959327.review:
ChilloutVR, a game like VRChat without EAC. If you like VRChat, i’m sure you’ll like ChilloutVR.

Pros and Cons.
•Pro, good alternative for VRChat if you don’t like EAC or you have a problem with VRChat.
• Con, Even tho ChilloutVR is very similar to VRChat, its not the same. You have to pay to upload more than 15 avatars from what i remember and you have to pay to upload more than a couple worlds. For me, it’s not really a problem but for other creators (ex: Cally3D) who don’t want to pay to upload avatars and or worlds. 
• Con, the game lags out very frequently due to all the new users coming from VRChat. (ex: everyone else frozen except for you)
• Pro, I like the things that make the game different. The big menu really is nice to the eye. 
• Pro, You only have to pay for the extras one time, unlike vrchat where its monthly.


ChilloutVR is a good alternative for VRChat but also a good game in general. It does have its errors and things along those lines but still. It’s a new game and still in development so you can’t blame it. 
I really do recommend it for people who can’t run VRChat because of EAC or just don’t like VRChat because of the new EAC. To anyone reading who wants to try it out, just a warning. Signing up for ChilloutVR isn’t the easiest. Be patient and you should get an email from ChilloutVR to verify your account in at least 24 hours.



PS: Thank you twitch.tv/Frost_Soar for the info for the last pro!

119922795.review:
This game is far from perfect.
Its obvious that its not "finished".
There are still a few quirks, and things that arent quite polished.
But at the end of the day, this game doesnt have eac and doesnt cease and desist mod developers. The devs are working hard, and making the game better. You dont disconnect randomly from instances anymore and the voice chat actually works now.
Porting worlds was fairly simple, although some features were missing from the sdk (they are in development).

I actually prefer the more simple style of making for example buttons and toggles.
Instead of weird udon scripts, the game uses an easy to understand modifier.
This might not be as flexible as udon, but its very simple, and i believe it will only get better over time.

The only thing this games lacks a bit is the playercount and amount of content available, but as this is all user-generated, it should get better as well.

Overall its a good game with a lot of potential, and the devs seem to be interested in using that potential.

119910699.review:
In the year 2023 this game has not gone unnoticed and the development team has proven their commitment on making this a finished game.

As I'm noting my Nomination for this years Labour of Love Award, I would like to add some few things to my overall review to the game:

From my profile you might already take to knowledge that I have spent some good amount of time in this game and other VR related ones. In this regard I find myself in the position to give a non biased view although through major issues with the competition it has come to find a place in my heart. The game is currently in Beta phase, I have played since the closed-Alpha version of the game. And I can say with confidence; a lot has changed. In other words this platform is a multitude more of a product than before. On the content side, it only lacks as the fresh community members who have since the debacle at the competition joined have started to experiment and learn on creating new worlds and avatars for everyone to enjoy. On the community services side; there are a multitude of clubs and events going on every week with tens of people at least. As the winter is coming we will see more people go online due to uncomfortable weather and this will definitely have a population increase. The game has gone through many issues and to the most part resolved them with the community, like a game should. Many issues still persists but with the small team, that they operate, they've come far and fast. Only seeing a uphill from here and there are good times to follow.

If you are looking for a nice chill evening or eventful weekend, this could be a platform to try out; there's a lot to do from chatting and racing with cars.

119878367.review:
To start off I'll be completely transparent. I tried this out a year ago when VRChat screwed modders over the first time and while it seemed promising, I went back to VRChat because they walked back on the reason I was checking this out. Now that the good modding community for VRC is effectively dead and VRC has made it clear they will not backtrack, I returned to try this out again and let me tell you, I'm extremely impressed.

First off, I want to say that the servers ARE a bit hard to log into currently. That is a valid issue right now but I ask that you don't let that turn you away. They got a massive influx of new users out of nowhere and weren't prepared but they are working FAST and expect it could be fixed by next week. Several of the mod creators within the modding community have actually joined the dev team and are helping improve the game. There is near-constant direct communication with the devs in the discord server. They are also perfectly ok with non-malicious mods being made for things they haven't gotten to yet. At this point I doubt I'd return to VRChat even if that game's devs DID revert EAC and allow modding.

This game has impressed me thoroughly, its flaws aside. I HIGHLY recommend checking it out especially if you're looking for somewhere to go besides VRChat, even if you want to wait until their servers are more stable first.

I've played VRC for years, and the lack of optimization and support from the DEV team kept pushing me away.
I tried the beta way back in the day for CVR, it seemed promising but I didn't stick around long.
Now with the advent of EAC I see no reason not to switch over, all the mod devs are coming. Belong Loader CVR, and EMMCVR is looking pretty good so far, and they've been getting support from the devs of CVR which is great.

The game itself feels more optimized than VRC, but there aren't as many worlds and they aren't as populated. The menu feels less user friendly, but that can be optimized over time or customized with mods. 119854707.review:
I've always had high hopes for the game, but I can't help but be a bit bothered by some things being pretty much the same 2 years later, such as:

• moving in desktop feeling like walking on ice (and the viewpoint not making sense unless you have head bobbing, which feels REAL weird)
• The documentation for working with its SDK (CCK) feels barebone and lacking
• The menu feels VERY weird to use, and is REALLY lacking some UX work
• (My opinion) Still not much to do. Like guys, come on, atleast some dumb minigame i can play with friends, that way you'll get a LOT more traction in the media (and people inviting their friends!)

Those are things that made me bothered 2 years ago and, playing it today, they seem to still be the same. I do have my high hopes that, with the player influx the game is getting now, that they will be able to give more attention to these things, other than the servers which are already being worked on.

Still, you listen to the community, ENCOURAGE them to work on their own workarounds, and in general are, well, not toxic towards your userbase. Honestly you're 10 steps ahead of VRChat simply due to that, and I am glad to see you receiving so many new users.



(also, some additional points:
• I feel like making a toggle for the camera to always be on top would be nice -- I'm not saying why tho :^)
• It would be nice to have a near clipping pane adjuster in the game (0.05, 0.01, 0.001 for instance), which I used to mod vrchat for. Depending on each world for that feels terrible.
• Being able to rejoin your own private instance would be nice
• When losing connection, you seem to have to entirely restart the game so you can join a lobby again
• Some more information on the 3.0-like animator system would be interesting

Those are some points off the top of my head that I remember bothering me, honestly with all of those fixed I feel like I'd never need a separate social VR platform at all.

Please, correct me if I missed something in any of the points, I am just displaying my own experience.)

119845043.review:
There is hope here, hope for a better platform for social VR, hope for a future where the developers do not prioritize investors over the playerbase.

so far, the overall framerate performance, camera functions, and tagging systems are highlights of the platform as a whole, in addition to an expressly laid out policy about allowed modding. 

these are all good things to have

presently, platform stability, some elements of avatar parameter interfaces, and a lack of scripting for worlds are lacking, and as is, are cons for the platform. 

this largely appears to be a result of a younger platform which has not reached its potential, particularly as a result of lack of funding and dev team size. 

With the ongoing developments hand in hand with the modding communities banished from VRchat, I can see this becoming a far better experience for players and creators, and as time goes on, I can only see more reasons appearing on the horizon to indicate a severe need for alternative social VR platforms to the dominant market players.

I would encourage those who seek to see this vision of what social VR can be reach fruition to support the platform in the ways they can.

119796897.review:
Despite being VERY early in development, ChilloutVR has a lot of potential now that it's grabbed... about 1% of VRChat's userbase thanks to the EAC update they pushed out without a care in the world. 1% is still a ton in this case, so! Let's check out the ups and downs of switching to Chillout.

First up: You don't have to deal with EAC or VRChat's bull! The devs actually listen to their community, which is really awesome. It means that, hopefully, we can actually get important things added before it becomes an issue.
Second: This game is basically VRChat combined with Neos, except with little downsides of both. You get avatars and props to play around with, and if Neos' in-game creation menu and items are anything to go by, people are gonna abuse the CCK to create some AMAZING things. I can already see it now.
Third: Chillout has PRELOADING! This means that you can load a world that you want to play in before joining, and not have to deal with sitting in a waiting menu for who knows how long, even if you have terrible internet! BRILLIANT! (As you can tell, I have bad internet. This concept is amazing.)
Fourth: You only need to pay a fee once to get all of the perks of this game, unlike a certain subscription-based model that another game employed. Beautiful.

Now for the cons of moving to Chillout instead of just staying and sitting in VRChat with it's now dying community.
First downside: Moving your avatars over to Chillout's CCK isn't as easy as pressing a few buttons in unity. Prefabs especially have an issue with this due to being so heavily built on the VRChat SDK. However, once people start figuring out the CCK for Chillout, I feel like things are gonna spiral out of control with how many avatars are ported over.
Second: This game is MASSIVELY in development, and a lot of things are gonna change over time. This is mostly good! However, it makes the game feel slightly unfinished at times. Only with the recent influx of players, bugs started showing up, and with bugs, comes people that like to ruin everyone's fun with said bugs. Props are being abused to crash others, but at least the devs are actually working on their game.
Third: The servers can't handle this many players. Like, at all. In it's current state, getting into a world with some folks to talk with is nearly impossible because the servers tend to kick you into a private, broken instance of a world if too many people join at once, forcing you to reboot the game. This is going to be fixed with time though, which is a nice thought.

Overall, this game is unfinished. Massively so. It's still in open alpha, so these things are expected to exist. Give it some time though, and Chillout is gonna be a BIG contender against VRChat, especially with the roads the two games are going down currently.

Do I suggest ChilloutVR? Yeah, absolutely! Do I suggest you play it now?... give it a chance, honestly. There are issues, yes, but YOU can help shape the future of this game by playing, discovering, and telling the devs if something odd pops up. As of the time of writing this review, however, I say give it a few weeks to cool down. Lots of players continuously trying to do stuff means that the game is bound to experience server crashes and such.

119759901.review:
As a VRChat refugee, the difference between the VRC developers and this game's devs is night and day. There's transparency, respect, and accountability to the community.

VRC Devs are beholden to investors, and any complaints go unheard. When EAC was announced, the entire community went into an uproar, but the VRC devs doubled down and said they would add "some" features into the game that mods already had allowed for. The admins in the Discord also banned many long-time players for criticizing the update, while also saying that people can have their opinions. I was banned for a week for "spreading misinformation" because I said that they may be trying to sell the game.

Meanwhile, the CVR devs have been continuously updating the community on the changes they've made to the API to allow for more players and load on their servers. They also hired VRChat mod developers to work on the game. The admins in the Discord, despite repeated questions and impatience by some players, kept a cool head and addressed questions instead of banning users. I think they understood that everyone was just tense and wanted a VRChat alternative immediately, which was, unfortunately, not possible. CVR devs are funded by the community via the Patreon and unlocked accounts purchased through Steam. 

Overall, I'm excited to see where this game goes, and I'm here for the journey.

119751718.review:
Update 1 (2023-07): So far so good. After nearly a year on the platform it's still good. It may not be as popular as VRChat, but it definitely has it's positive aspects.
Social aspects:
- No (or at least significantly less) children running around in meme avatars,
- A few active communities with reliable weekly events,
- Official community guides which can help you if you find the game confusing at first,
- Welcoming and supportive users.

Game / platform mechanics/capabilities:
- Prop system which is independent of user avatars and/or worlds.
- Mod support with active modding scene.
- 11 point (or more ? not sure) Full body tracking with up to 64 trackers.
- Haptics support,
- Newly released update to Unity 2021 with performance improvements.
- Search system which includes not only public worlds, but avatars, props and users,
- Robust private avatar sharing system (no need to make an avatar public and cloneable if you want to share it only with one friend),
- More granular and more advanced safety and avatar / prop fileting system. Limit or entirely disable unwanted stuff - down to specific components.
- A lot of commonly used prefabs (DPS, Audio Link, etc.) "Just work:tm:".
- No need to hide props on avatars - nor fiddle with janky world constraints - thanks to the prop system.

So far - Highly recommend.


Original Review (2022-07): Hopefully will succeed where VRChat has failed.

119725625.review:
So, like probably many. I'm giving CVR a chance after the whole VRC announcement.

With this review, I'm recommending it for now, well, conditionally.
It has its good sides and it has it’s downsides.
The good:
-	It runs better than VRC
-	Migrating avatars/worlds from VRC to CVR is easy
-	The options menu in CVR offers a LOT of options that VRC is simply missing
-	The ability to place your own props and have others play with them is interesting
-	The content controls on the user side are a pretty great addition.
-	The ability to pre-load before visiting is pretty good.
The bad:
-	Due to the influx of new players, there are a LOT of API issues (that hopefully will get ironed out)
-	The UI looks clunky and non-intuitive. It’s hard to tell when there’s nothing there or it’s simply loading things.
-	A lot of the systems and features you come to expect from VRC are simply missing.
-	The UI Lags on things it shouldn’t lag on.
-	Using interactables is non-intuitive. 
-	Still no content encryption making it trivial to steal others content.
-	Controls feel off, gravity feels off.
-	It lacks feedback on a lot of things, both auditory and physical feedback. It honestly took me a while to realize my speakers weren’t busted.
All in all, though, I’m recommending it because it does show potential. Plus, competition is always good for the industry. But it still has a long road ahead of it to be considered on par with VRC.

119686680.review:
The Devs have an extraordinary opportunity at this point in time, to take in a large collaborative community of people who love working together to make a world people can escape in.  Their primary competitor among VR social rooms who has been dominating the market for a long while has pushed out a large part of their community and that mass group of people need a new home.  ChilloutVR COULD be their home, but there is much that needs to be done.  I am optimistic, with the help of a growing community and a whole lot of passion for this escape, CVR can quickly become that new home for the Mods community and hopefully a home for a major portion of the social VR space in general.  I see so much potential here for growth and sculpting a world that everyone can be a part of and feel comfortable and more than satisfied in.  The vision I, and many others, have for this game can only be fulfilled through a strong community first policy from the devs and lots of love and care from the player base.  I have no reason to believe that this game's Devs have any sort of plans down the road to put a lid on the Mod community as their competitor has and I hope they keep it this way.  I know I am not alone when I say I have spent a LOT of time on their competitor's game and a recent update they released, despite overwhelming backlash, felt like a spit in the mouth more so than a slap in the face...  I think these Devs, now swarmed with a new influx of players, observed this self destructive behavior of their competitor, and I pray they steer clear of making the same mistake.  Though their competitor may get by just fine, many will not forget their refusal to listen to the desires of their community and a large sum of players will not be returning at least for some period of time after this break of trust.  I am happy to be a part of CVR's discord community and have been watching them stagger but re-balance and plant themselves in hard work and dedication to their game.  As I pay attention to each announcement in their discord server I grow eager and I am impressed with their resolve.  This game in its current state has some catching up to do, by no fault of their own as they had no idea this would happen.  I see many features, I always wished was in their competitor's game, already natively installed into their base game and I see so much potential to add and explore new ideas in this game, given the community sees the same potential I do.

I believe it is important to show support to such a small Dev team, that cares so much about their game, and I hope many people do.  You don't have to choose sides and ONLY play CVR, though I know many people will after what I will refer to as "the event".  Some day many social VR games may coexist as most social media we think of today; insta, FB, twitter, etc., but at this moment I believe CVR has the chance to be a freer form of social VR and truly let people create within their giant sandbox of a game and grow in many directions.

As I stated, the Devs have lots of work to do, but I believe the growth of this game will be exponential once the theoretical ball starts rolling.

I know ya'll might be tired of these "VRChat Refugee" or "I came from VRChat" kinda reviews, etc etc, but I will make that portion quick

Obviously I came to this game looking for some form of a VRChat alternative, and before all of that, I'd say I had a good time with VRC, spending over 1,000 hours in said game over the span of 3 in a half years. But of course all things mustn't last forever

Okay, now for the real stuff, and that is about ChilloutVR, now despite almost everyone from VRC talking high praise on this game, I still came in with little to no expectations, I thought this was gonna be a sorta meh version of VRChat, and even with the one hour I did go through in this game, it's actually way more than that, the fact that there are so many settings and accessibility options all native inside the game with no mods, clients, and whatnot? That is amazing. There were somethings I was unable to find when searching certain avatars (Was looking for Lucia from Punishing Gray Raven) but I will assume that it's just that the game might not have as many or too many public avatars, if that's a thing, if I am wrong on that I do apologize!

As for connecting to worlds, it is seamless as hell and I love it, the transitions from the current world to the one you are trying to join is great, oh and seeing who is in certain worlds is just an added bonus honestly. I have had the issue of the servers messing up on me, which of course is not the fault of the devs, it's just that so many people are coming in at once so it is a bit to handle, so it's no biggie.

In terms of things that I can compare to VRC, I kinda wish there was a toggle mute/unmute on the controller so I don't have to open the quick menu for that, unless there is a button for such in the settings or something and I missed it, and the camera seeming a little hard to use, mostly due to me not being used to it, and then there's.... oh wait that's kinda it actually, really nothing else to major besides that.

Overall, I think ChilloutVR is a great, if not amazing alternative to VRChat, especially considering the BS that is going on there. I do not know if I will stick with ChilloutVR for a while until VRChat fixes their mess, or if there is a work around for me to have my normal stuff in VRC, which both probably won't happen. Either way, I plan to check out this game a lot more, to see all that can be seen. I look forward to seeing how far this game will grow

119676786.review:
CVR has a mindboggling amount of potential, and is proof that monopolies smother effort and innovation.

People may ask "If it's so good, why wasn't anybody talking about it"? You see it all over the gaming space, hell, even a game like Final Fantasy 14 was once under that kind of umbrella. I give you this:

Monopoly is the bane of innovation and the killer of growth. There is a reason the Government made monopolies illegal. Companies can and will do the bare minimum to appease the customer while draining every coin the can, which is why monopolies are illegal-- if monopolies reigned, there would be no innovation, and stagnation will set in.

How does this relate at all to this review? I'm glad you asked.

VRChat has had a monopoly over the VR Social Experience for nearly half a decade now. This is not due to having the objectively best experience, nor is it because it lacks competition — it has what no other Social VR Platform has: A large community. VRChat started early, as one of the first Social VR games, and it has been growing since then, and has become THE Social VR Experience, and has actually killed off a number of other budding platforms by rendering them barren of players. Except for one.

Introducing Chillout VR. A small, humble VR Social App running of Patreon funds. It averages single digit user counts and is really just a small place to hang out with your friend group, which may include the devs. By all means, CVR should have followed the fate of, for example, Sansar. But it didn't, and the devs and the tiny community they'd grown stuck with the game. And as we've seen, in the end, it was worth it.

CVR is, from a software standard, better in MANY ways. Better performance, graphics, graphical settings, UI, SDK (in my experience so far) and locomotion options. A number of things that were mods in VRC, such as no clip, are also part of the base game. CVR also allows non-malicious mods to be used on their platform.

However, despite all of these things, CVR was still doomed. Because like any other new social VR platform, the sentiment was the same. "That new thing looks cool, but all my friends and worlds and avatars are on VRChat". And for a very long time... That was the status quo. Despite its superior software, it just didn't have the social attraction it needed. Until now.

VRChat introduces EAC (Easy Anti-cheat) in an attempt to prevent crashers, hackers, and modders from having the ability to do what they do. However, the VRC team forgot some things... One: EAC Bypass methods are literally common knowledge. Two: Crashers use avatars, not external software. Three: Mods are not objectively malicious: in fact, many were used for accessibility, improving performance, etc. People were mad. VRChat has now gone from an highs of 35k users and lows of 20k users before EAC to Highs of 20k and lows of 15k after EAC. VRChat has effectively halved its userbase over night due to EAC... And this is where Chillout VR comes in.

With this massive blunder, the VRC devs forgot something in their complacency: VRChat is kept alive by good will and the community. And if you piss off the community, they can leave or find something else to do. Something else to play. And here is Chillout VR. Better software. Better SDK. Better performance. Allowing mods. Chillout DESERVES its newfound playerbase, and I genuinely hope that it continues to see success as things go on. This will not kill VRChat, make no mistake: But as the recent flurry of dev updates have show, its lit a fire under their ass to actually do some work.

I recommend Chillout VR. The devs deserve it for their work, and frankly? Players deserve better than VRChat, because the devs of VRChat are clearly no longer the handful of devs that put together the game for no profit back in 2017.

119675250.review:
My recommendation is a skeptical one. I've been on-and-off involved with the Chillout community and followed development since the beginning, in the original Closed Alpha that I donated to get into. After nearly 200 hours between Chillout itself and the ChilloutVR Discord, I think I have a firm grasp on the core community and the rate of development, and I would like to share my thoughts now, while the platform is gaining record traffic as a result of external dramas on related platforms.
1: Development is painfully slow. I've watched several times, as peeple get a massive amount of hype over the next update adding new features, only for the features to either not be really worth the hype in the end, or to get scaled back and/or delayed repeatedly. The biggest difference I can see between Closed Alpha of years ago, and now, is that they finally added a hand menu for quick access to basic options.
2: The UI is extremely lacking, and issue-prone. The menus with network-related options do not refresh themselves, the filters barely work, and the entire layout feels disjointed to use.
3: Bad performance is handled far worse. In some cases, ChilloutVR will easily outperform VRChat, I won't deny that. But, if you're in a situation or on hardware where Chillout does *not* run very well, it is significantly more noticeable and headache-inducing than how VRChat or NEOS handle it. I'm not sure I can even describe it, but it makes Chillout the hardest platform of the three for me to deal with on my GTX 1050-equipped laptop, and while I have a more powerful main system, the experience on the lower end hardware is still very notable, as it signifies a much harsher hardware barrier to use the platform, especially in VR.
If you can deal with these points of criticism I've provided against ChilloutVR, then I will say, it's a pretty good Social VR platform to use in place of or alongside its competitors.

119654745.review:
Ohhh boy. 

If you're looking for a Social VR experience right now this is the place to go. It has insanely good performance compared to every other option, it has global graphics settings, an astoundingly granular saftey and content filtering options, and NSFW content is opt-in only, and requires the user to be of the age of majority in their country, or 18, whichever is higher. 

If you're moving from VRChat to here, welcome, take a seat, don't mind the fire, that's the 10,000 other people trying to join a the same time, it'll even out over the next few days. You're in for a treat, massive performance improvements, SUPER-EASY avatar conversion from your already existing VRC ones, natively supported Dynamic Bones and dynamic bone interactions, Magica cloth for true cloth physics, native flight support, and a prop system that allows you to bring a lightsaber and toss it to your friend before having a brutal duel. Or pull out a truck and drive around. Maybe you want to fly a plane about? Props baby! Oh, built in avatar, player, and world search capability, as well as full mod support. 

These guys asked "what if we did VR better?" and this was their answer, and it is glorious.

119654661.review:
-native face and eye tracking using Tobbi Eye (vive pro for example) (the one in VRChat takes up OSC and only runs at 15hz; the mapping isn't very good either)
-native IKTweaks (IKTweaks dev is in the Discord helping them now even more)
-native b-haptics
-better performance/lower CPU overhead because the original codebase is not from 2016
-allows all non-malicious open source mods, which have to be curated by the devs
-if it is done well, the devs might just ask to use the code directly to save them time and add a feature people want, the importance of this can not be understated.
-much more advanced systems for sharing avatars: You can upload avatars to other people's account using a temporary key; you can share avatars with people who are whitelisted, you can share it with them and then transfer ownership, plus you can share private avatars with specific people
-no rippers, all avatar data is actually encrypted and doesn't just come in a unitypackage (lmao) And the devs really hate rippers, I trust that they will work on more measures if it gets cracked.
-public avatars are searchable, same way you can search for worlds
-spawnable props including cars, guns, and anything you can think of
-props are searchable same way worlds and avatars are searchable
-more up-to-date engine versions, they switched to 2019 months before VRChat did, and they were in the process of switching to 2021, but then this happened
-much better netcode: things like avatar ripping, UDON crashes, IP leaks, are all inherent problems in VRChat's netcode which the VRC team doesn't seem to want to fix. All known crashes are fixed here, the netcode is very robust and runs at a greater refresh rate than VRChat's. The devs take pride in this one in particular, I trust they will work quickly when exploits are found.
-better culling, things you don't see on the avi get unrendered whenever an update occurs in the world (like someone switches avatars) meaning there is less things being rendered all the time
-you can block specific parts of avatars. like you can block loud sounds, gore, nudity, size constraints, flashing/bright lights and much more, and then only those parts are hidden. [This is a feature plan, only partially implemented so far.]
-you can search for NSFW content, it's tagged as such and can be hidden, or specifically looked for
-more avatar parameters (3200 instead of 256)
-seperate voice position (the voice actually is coming out of the avatar's mouth)
-magica cloth simulation support which is super performant and interactive as well, doesn't just rely on bones but can use vertices as well.
-there are no loading screens, worlds are pre-downloaded in the background and everything has a button for preloading
-very good speech visemes: I don't remember the technical name for this, but everyone liked the mouth movement and thought it looked a lot better than VRC when people talked
-an actual fucking youtube search natively in the video player, youtube playlists are supported too! You can even create and modify playlists in the game.
-more favorites: 8 categories of 100 favs (so 800) for free, and 32 categories of 100 (so 3200) for unlocked
-amazing camera, you have a native camera drone and even more options, it's close to VRClens in features. You can use just hand gestures to take photos, it's extremely cool: make a picture frame with your fingers to spawn the camera, then clap and to despawn it. (this is optional)
-the camera also works in desktop mode.
-no kids in public since it's not on quest (it's true lol)
-the SDK has an automatic quick system to create avatar toggles
-avatar parameters can be triggered by particles (you can actually shoot people if they allow it for example)
-offline lobbies are a thing, for example you can quick disconnect from an instance and people will disappear but the world around you stays as it was
-you can fly! (world creators can disallow this)


I know it also has had better dynamic bones performance, avatar dynamics and interactive dynamic bones about a year before VRChat had it.

Porting avatars and worlds is very simple with not many steps (ported my first avatar in literally 10 minutes) because it's all the same engine and has support for the same shaders.

119652716.review:
Wait a few years, then maybe it'll be functional. Notice in the videos they don't show the UI, or players using portals, etc. There's a REALLY GOOD REASON. They're bad. Really bad. The following is my response when someone asked why I didn't like it:

Cons:
1: holy cow the UI is so bad, they use the trigger to both drag AND select things, but prioritize dragging over selecting- meaning if you try to click ANYTHING, you better have the steady hands of a surgeon.
2: what even is discovery? how do you find anything? ah yes, the search bar... BUT 80% of the time you search for anything, you'll get a vague error, not even a "0 results found"
3: ooh look a portal! click [full menu opens]... and that's it. it just opens. doesn't navigate to the world, doesn't search for the world name, doesn't teleport you to the world, just opens the menu. And walking through it does nothing
4: keybinds menu... doesn't have keybinds in VR, just a handful of toggles... not even for what button does what
5: to jump, you... get this... click down either joystick. A button does nothing, in any context
6: keyboard and text boxes are as bad as VRChat
7: no support for left-handed people (see Pro 2 for context)
8: a LOT of the settings are redundant, and could use a single master toggle; in order to enable ALL NSFW content, you need to enable NSFW content for avatars twice, props twice, for Adult and Potentially Adult (or whatever)
9: the only world I could use (the default spawn area) is SO BIG it takes upwards of a minute to get from spawn to the portals, and double that to go to anywhere else after that


Pros:
1: built-in media controls for listening to your desktop's music and controlling it
2: left top button opens small menu, right top button opens big menu
3: built-in search includes worlds, avatars, users, AND props (basically, objects like swords and shit, presumably- I never could find anything no matter what I searched)
4: I got 90fps, whereas VRChat softlocks you to at most 45 in most cases
5: big menu is placed wherever you're looking, no matter the orientation- including upside-down and sideways. and it's world-placed

119604885.review:
Everyone here talking about how VRChat bad now, lets ignore VRChat right now. 

Chillout VR (CVR) is wonderful so far. Yes its servers are having issues, but be patient. The current Dev team is very small and did not anticipate the influx of new users. At the time of this review they've said in their discord that there's going to be a maintenance period that'll be roughly 8-10 hours. 

If we're comparing directly with VRChat, CVR has a bunch of stuff that VRChat does not. 
+ Cleaner, More Advanced UI
+ Significantly More Optimized (Does not hog your CPU as much as VRChat)
+ Mod Friendly (Devs Support Mods, and have even hired former mod creators of VRChat)
+ Avatar Search
+ Search Tags
+ Unlimited Favorites (Technically, the limit is 800, which is essentially Unlimited)
+ Movable Menus
+ Native Toggle Noclip on Certain Worlds
+ Can Call Friends Directly Within the Game
+ An Inventory System for Props
+ The Ability to Use a VPN While Playing (Stay Secure my Friends)
+ Actual Graphics Settings
+ Actual Settings in General
   And I can't forget
+ A Free NSFW DLC to Enable Viewing of NSFW Content ( A favorite among many users :) 

Things VRChat has that CVR Does not Have:
- Easy Ant-Cheat (Sorry, but I had to mention it.)

Download this when you can. Its free and it'll become more stable soon.
I am aware that VRC announced some future features that I listed it doesn't have, but at this time VRC doesn't have them.

This game is what a platform like this should look like. For one, go read the ToS and compare it to VRChat's ToS. It is so much better. Next is just the developer themselves being so much better than VRChat in terms of behavior, design philosophy, and more. Lastly, the fact that with the game being as small as it is has several features that blow VRChat out of the water just shows how little VRChat cares. 

I can't stress enough how impressed I am with this game just at this point and the recent statements from them and VRChat has shown who actually understands how to run a game and community. Hint, it's not VRChat.

If you want a place to put your money, this is it. After they get things rolling and built up for the new influx I will certainly be dropping my money into them.

119602271.review:
I've been trying to like Chillout VR for two days now, but it's just been two days of pointless annoyance. "Server Issues", which another reviewer tried to excuse, are one thing - but unfortunately also a crucial drawback, especially when you're repeatedly thrown out of the game and have to restart the program. Which never works, because it can't be closed properly, so you regularly have to kill the entire Steam interface and restart everything. When it does work, the user interface isn't exactly accessible either. Today, after I left initial "Server Issues" behind, I got stuck with the error "Failed to login using provided credentials". Several restarts didn't change anything (with the same correct credentials I successfully used yesterday). Other options, perhaps to reset passwords or to check the account - missing.
After having spent half an hour on technical problems today, without even getting into the program, I'm gone for the time being, because my time is too valuable for that. Unfortunately, I have to add that I never had comparable problems with VR Chat, neither before nor after the controversial update - so all in all, I would say that the platform is not only overwhelmed, but unfortunately also underdeveloped and currently offers no usable alternative ... not even to NeosVR, which is still rather in the development phase but still offered more in-game user experience compared to technical problem solving.

P.S.: I definitely understand that a lot of people who have joined in the last few days are really annoyed with VRChat and just wish ChilloutVR to be an alternative. But at the end of the day it has to be said that the "more politically correct positioning" of a software is no substitute for usability. And the latter is just not given at the moment, so it doesn't help anyone to gloss over that by writing even more reviews that only praise the developers for their stance on mods and nonchalantly brush over the technical issues.

119599236.review:
ChilloutVR has always been a little rough around the edges, however, it appears we have the chance for something very great. VRChat developers have caused a massive uproar and as a result many users are considering ChilloutVR a possible replacement, so let's talk about why you should keep an eye on this one.

This will be a little bit of a short one with my limited experience, but here is multiple reasons you should give this a try. While typically you should review a product based on it's standalone qualities, I will do a comparison to VRChat instead as it's currently more apt to do.
[list]
[*]There is a toy/prop feature that allows you to have objects you can spawn in that aren't part of your avatar. This is light years ahead of VRChat in terms of user interaction as a result.
[*]Compared to VRChat there is a MASSIVE amount of settings you can change including your graphics settings.
[*]I can't believe I have to say this, but unlike VRChat you can actually set your graphics resolution...
[*]The servers are being improved to accommodate the quickly growing user count. While at the moment you'll have difficulties connecting, this probably won't be the case later. Both user funding and servers are increasing in size.
[*]On boarding mod developers from the recent VRChat debacle. Instead of threatening mod creators with a cease and desist... they just hire them! The same great people who made our fantastic mods and loading systems will help speed up the development and improve quality of CVR itself.
[*]Minor or massive improvements to framerate vs something like VRChat.
[*]CVR has an official modding toolkit for making mods that fall under acceptable usage. Terms of Service regarding this located [url=https://documentation.abinteractive.net/official/legal/tos/#7-modding-our-games]here.[/url]
[*]As of current there is no Anti Cheat system and VRChat serves as an excellent example of an awful way to add Anti Cheat software. We can expect their decisions to be different because of it alongside the fact the team has ex-VRChat modders on it.
[*]There is tutorials, scripts, and tools for porting your VRChat avatars and content to ChilloutVR.
[*]Your friends COULD be going here and will find it closer to VRChat than something like NeosVR.
[*]No crypto, no microtransactions, and for the most part very low monetization as of current. You can support them through Patreon or with an unlocked account for like 7 dollars which gives you unlimited avatar/world uploads. By default you have 10 avatars/worlds without this purchased, which isn't too bad.
[*]UI isn't finished, we can expect them to work on it more.
[*]A Unity upgrade was planned but interrupted temporarily by the massive migration of users. Newer unity features will be on the way as well.
[/list]

119592666.review:
KEEP IN MIND: At the time of writing this review, the game is dealing with an influx of players, certain systems aren't working, and likely won't be for a little bit. Do not let this push you away, cause this has the makings of something very impressive.

I will also be updating this review when I get a chance to try it in VR, but I've heard it runs a lot smoother than the other games. 

While I've only spent a few minutes tinkering around in game, in desktop mode no less, it's shown that this is something to keep an eye on. Not only are there better options for filtering avatars (filtering based off tags added by creators, rather than blanket turning off specific functions), with said filters also applying to worlds too, the other systems in place also really beat out the competition. 

It's clear that the dev team is passionate about this game, and are willing to work with the community too, which is amazing to see, here's hoping the new numbers won't cause them too many issues however. 

One thing to note, while the free version of this game doesn't have any significant differences compared to the "Unlocked Account", you are limited with how many avatars you can upload. 10 for the free account, and unlimited for a ONE TIME $8 payment. 

Highly recommend it.

119591702.review: ChilloutVR is one of the best Social VR applications out there, especially given recent updates to one of their competitors. Even before that happened though, ChilloutVR showed itself as a true competitor to VRChat and other social VR platforms, with new features that really improve the experience and possibilities within the game. There are many features in the game by default that other games like VRChat require mods for (which the devs killed), or simply don't have at all, including face tracking, haptics, world interactions with avatars, wind on dynamic bones, a better portaling system, spawnables, and a plethora of allowed third party components such as improved cloth simulations, terraining and vegetation tools, dynamic clouds, and level of detail. And all of this is not to mention the fact that the developers explicitly allow non malicious modding, meaning that any features that are lacking can be added by the community. This game is, and in my opinion always has been superior to its competitors in multiple ways, and now with a push to use other platforms, this game could become a true competitor in the world of social VR

And just like vrchat took time to develop this game needs time to develop. People shouldn't be so quick to judge, that being said me personally until they develop more. Sadly I won't get the chance to participate, it's not the developer's fault of  I'll chill out VR. However, I'm going to have to stick with what I know. My reason being is because although it sucks that my mods are gone. The menu is easier to understand, so this is my feedback to you chill out VR. Please try to make a simpler menu, also the colors are very straining on the eyes it was actually very painful in my headset and actually cause me a headache after only a few minutes of being in your game. The green and white aesthetic it's just really harsh on the eyeballs. However your world creation and presentation is beautiful. But because you're not used to the massive influx of people they optimization is sadly lacking. I look forward to logging on again in the future and hopefully at some point being able to upload avatars. I'll be patiently eagerly looking forward to when I'll be able to participate. However I'm going to have to wait and the game has advanced a bit further. So this is not meant to be a negative review, in all honesty I'm very excited to see the community grow for this game. However like I said there are a few things that are just not very compatible. I said the biggest selling point for me that is why I'm probably not going to be playing it is because I am a full-body user and my full body system did not work.  From my personal experience I was loading up the game it was not able to register my finger tracking, or my hip movements. And sadly because I spent so much on my system I want to be able to play a game where I'm actually able to still continue dancing. So as I said it's not meant to be negative review but I'm hoping that it's some point chillout VR can move Beyond vrchat. 119563885.review:
Lemme say this ChilloutVR was dead game for solid amount of time because no one was interested in this game. Now its best alternative to Vrchat. Camera? Already better than VRC and with some functions from VRClens for example dron UwU. 

But be aware that Alpha Blend Interactive is really tiny team of developers they have hard time to manage sudden flow of new players. So be patient.

[b] Oculus/Meta Quest Support [/b]
Not Yet , but planned.

[b] Calls in game [/b]
There is only placeholder in main menu... this feature is not ready yet and will be there in the future. So please dont ask how to use that. This is common question at their discord.

[b] Can i use in game camera for making photos at desktop? [/b]
Yes, you can! And i think with push of left Alt or double push... you can lock you camera in place for while and you can click at buttons at camera with mouse cursor.

[b] Is modding game client okay? [/b]
Absolutely as long as you follow this TOS and not make malicious mod. https://documentation.abinteractive.net/official/legal/tos/#7-modding-our-games

[b] Do i need to buy unlocked account? [/b]
Nope you dont need to do it. Normaly you can upload max 10 avatars with unlocked account its problably like hundred/s. And if you support them with Patreon (10+ USD tier)  then you will get unlimited amount of  uploads. But for most people free or unlocked acc is enough. So dont worry.

[b] Is NSFW allowed? [/b]
As long as you mark your avatar or prop with correct tags.. then yes.  And also you need to download free dlc ''mature content'' if you wanna see others players with NSFW. Which only players which have 18+ steam account can see. And if someone younger will be caught with that DLC, then that person can be banned. So if you dont have at least 18, dont try to get that.

And my final words, Alpha Blend Interactive need your support so if you cancelled VRC+ you can be their patreon without problems, they dont have private investors they use money from Patreon. Here is the link https://www.patreon.com/AlphaBlendInteractive/posts

And also if you have some skill in development of games you can try apply for some possition here  team@abinteractive.net

Over the time I had come to known this game I've had a decent time. Sure it was a little confusing at 1st to make avatars and stuff but since I knew how to do it on VRC, it wasn't that hard to learn. The people I've met here were ''chill''. Even the youth. But I went back to VRC in may to see how things were.... and woo boy... It got worse. And with the eac in vrc I understand everyone's annoyance. I don't use mods in truth so I'm not bothered with VRC. But here, YOU ARE MORE THAN WELCOMED. As much as I am sad for VRC, cause I want competition between the 2 so they don't get lazy and make their game bad but it looks like VRC is doing that already, I am glad Chillout is getting more and more popular. Don't worry about the small player count and current lack of stuff to do, think of it as a canvas for a masterpiece painting, it's a blank piece just waiting to be filled with wonderful magic. You have the chance, and now it's up to you to make the IMPACT!

Edit: They also have a discord server as well. The devs show a clear interest in their playerbase and what they have to say.

119546101.review:
ChilloutVR is an up-and-coming social vr platform that has been kickstarted into relevance by VRChat's terrible response to its modding community and anticheat. After the initial influx of refugees, it has already significantly improved server stability, has been highly communicative with users on discord, and hired some people from the former VRC modding community to help build their platform. If they keep this up, then the future is bright for Alpha Blend Interactive. They are showing what community-driven - not shareholder-driven - social vr should look like.  
CVR already has many features the modding community from VRC has been asking for for years - like flight/noclip (can be disabled by world authors), global optimized dynamic bones, built in bhaptics and face tracking support, youtube video search, and NSFW content filtering, among so much more. A new form of content creation is also present: props. I've seen props range from bonk hammers to NERF guns, to a Minecraft building system. With future updates coming, like a server-side world scripting system, the potential for ChilloutVR content is nearly limitless. So if you'd like a change of pace from an out of touch, nearly radio-silent developer team to one that encourages the innovation that modding brings, and cares about their community? Then now is the perfect time to give ChilloutVR a try!

119545034.review:
[h1] Go play this instead of VRChat [/h1]
This game is [b] FAR [/b] superior to VRChat. Now that VRC has shot itself in the foot thanks to the new anti-cheat, this will provide an opportunity for this game to rise up and become the newer and better VRC. There are plenty of reasons why this game is better:
- The developer actually listens to its community instead of destroying it with garbage updates
- The users are much more mature and not infested with crybaby kids
- No crashers or annoying avatars
- Has features that VRChat should have added a long time ago
Of course, this game does have flaws, albeit pretty minor:
- The menu is sort of a nightmare to navigate, though the dev might overhaul it
- There are some furry players which can pose a problem to those who hate them
- Servers are lagging like crazy due to the influx of players, but the devs are working on it
Overall though, this game is fantastic and a superior alternative to VRChat. I highly recommend spreading word on this game so it can grow and thrive like it deserves to.

119518039.review:
I'm pretty impressed with this platform. While it's definitely struggling with the server load, it has its own unique aesthetic, performs well, and has a lot of cool features built into the avatar creator and the game itself. I'm not a game dev and couldn't make a 3d model in blender to save my life, but I got my avatar loaded in even with custom sitting animations in no time. Also I only replaced the one because wow their animations are nice, except maybe the landing one.

My advice to the devs as they hire and grow is to also getting a UX designer on staff. Normally most platforms get annoying with constant UX designs but the interface of both the website and the app look like something I'd do as a software engineer if I was given a list of feature specs but no UX design for them, and it's a bit confusing.

But with all the features, excellent handling of adult content and general ToS policies explicitly allowing commonly desired player actions under reasonable guidelines, and easy migration to get vtuber or other VR a avatars into this app, I have incredibly high hopes for this game.

Alright. I gave it a very short test run.
And remember. This game had almost no playerbase until yesterday so they do not have the network infrastructure to run the game with this insane increase in traffic. SHOW PATIENCE PEOPLE.

This game seems amazing on a surface level. But small dev team and heavy influx of traffic is gonna choke it for a while.The summary is.
Lots of QOL features.
No punishing/entrapping adult content needlessly
A somewhat overwhelming UI
Nonexistent servers outside of EU/AS
Player influx effectively DDOSing their servers with traffic.

Negative:
The game is not set up with enough infrastructure for the new influx of traffic. American servers are nonexistent currently so keep that in mind.
If you are migrating from VRChat, The menus will take some getting used to and traversing between worlds can feel strange.
You have to go the their website to edit you profile.
Due to network issues. Ping is incredibly high and instances are crashing often.
The transition between worlds, though kinda nice, is horrible for your eyes.
The menu is very complicated for those not used to larger UI's

Positive:
So many QOL features. A lot of it simple settings I didn't realise I needed.
The notification system seems like it will be a HUGE imporvement over VRC.
The little of the community I have met is very friendly and more than excited to have the influx of traffic despite the issues with servers being out the window right now. Most communities would attack those that are disrupting their usual vibe.
You can pre load worlds instead of waiting in the loading screen forever depending on internet and such.
Individual avatar save states. Meaning avatars that are heavily customisation can be saved in multiple states to easily load instead of always having to readjust the whole avatar (Or so i assume by the feature, I havent gotten my hands on a avatar with the ability to properly test it)
Able to upload/spawn props


Once again, SO MANY SETTINGS FOR QOL AND BASIC SHIT BRO. WE VIBIN.

119512883.review:
An alternative to VRChat that is practically better in every way.
This game does not contain an invasive Anti-Cheat like EAC, thus making the platform much safer and Proton compatible.
The base game is FAR BETTER in terms of optimization than VRChat, even with lots of custom avatars in a single world.
Paying to unlock your account, while odd if you're coming from a platform like VRChat, makes sense as you're making a one time payment for more storage space on the cloud servers of the developers (Which is NOT free and costs them a lot more than they charge us!)
You can still upload 10 avatars on your own without the upgrade, but its very much worth supporting the developer team.

119496327.review:
Chillout VR is a platform for VR content supported by a friendly development team. A great amount of care has been taken to make the experience as comfortable as possible. There's a lot of small quality of life things, and it helps that the performance is really good.

Here's a few things that really stood out to me
 - Video players have a search feature! you can search for videos within VR instead of having to do it externally
 - The Game runs really good. I'm using the exact same avatar running on the exact same world and my performance is better than other unity based social vr applications running the exact same content.
- the Avatar SDK is really nice to work with. You can really easily set things to be toggled within the SDK without making animations, but you can still use animations if you want.
- Group system where you can set up group events and make worlds only joinable to group members
- The devs have an open stance about modding on their terms of service. Mods are fine as long as they're open source and not malicous!

Honestly I really hope this platform takes off.

I haven't  had any problems with this game; not sure why there are even any down votes other than maybe VRchat fans getting upset that this game and others like NEOSVR exists. 

Major Pros

- there is no elite system or wait time to upload avatars and environments.
- you can invite friends to private worlds or upload an open world for others to visit.(you can do both of course)

116118437.review:
In the twenty or so minutes of playing this, I saw only ONE active instance in the entire game. And even then, it was only two people. TWO PEOPLE. I could literally start a public world in VRChat and would it be bouncing with randos in five minutes. I don't know if this game peaked before I ever got the chance to dive into it, or VRChat's shadow is too large to escape, but it felt like the Mojave in there.

The paywall to have access to Mature Content? Good idea to help keep things tame and filtered.
But, why go through a paywall to look at VR tiddy when you can just find a NSFW avatar in no time, for free, on VRC? It's 2022, people are gonna go with the easier solution to get their rocks off.

Degeneracy aside, the game looks smooth and felt smooth, as I was playing through a desktop streamer on my Quest 2. Turning was clunky, I was hoping there'd be an option for smooth rotation, and I'm not a fan of the Turn Degree mechanic.

For something that feels like a polished VRChat, it sure is dead. The best comparison I can make is this:
ChilloutVR, for all of its efforts, is Westworld. VRChat, for all of its bugs, performance strain, and degeneracy, is the true Wild West.

If I want to have some fun in VR, I'm going to the Wild West. If I could select an option that isn't a Thumb Up or Thumbs Down, I would. The potential is there for ChilloutVR, but I think it's just trapped in the shadow of VRChat.

In addition, you can change the turn mechanic by turning off snap turning in the input settings.

112300438.review:
**an honest review**
I've changed my mind about chilloutvr and decided to stop being an optimist and write an honest review of my actual thoughts, instread of the fantasy potential ones of my last review. I wouldn't trust the good reviews of this game, as they were the result of a mass review spam because people were having a temper tantrum about an entirely different game, and not because cvr was deserving of it. Before the mass temper tantrum, this game did awful. It had maybe 20 people maximum and most of them was just moderation and a few hoity toity people who whined about vrchat. This game had a reputation of being the bootleg version of vrchat, and it honestly was. It centered its entire community around hating vrchat. It was a toxic environment which drove most people away in the beginning. I joined a long time before the massive temper tantrum fiasco, and my honest thoughts were, "this game is sub par. It has no substance." The worlds were just shittily ported from VRChat, except with a  bootleg, dinosaur layout. Terribly optimized, and we ultimately stopped playing because of the safety settings, they're ATROCIOIUS. My boyfriend at the time has epilepsy, and couldn't disable people's avatars which can be falesly mislabeled to do strobes for everyone and you can't disable it. My boyfriend had a seizure and I've felt a tinge of rage ever since because of that. 

The UI, was, and still is, terrible. Much worse than that, the community is TERRIBLE. The moderation is terrible. TERRIBLE PEOPLE.

I tried coming back quite a few times and honestly left in tears on my final time. It's overwhelmingly toxic. Everything bad about vrchat, including the crashers and obnoxious avatars and annoyingly cruel players who drop slurs and harass you, picked up and ran to chilloutvr. My first several impressions were all the same-- it's uncomfortable. I couldn't really have that conversation that i can in other social platforms because of all the screaming and craziness that often times my voice would be drowned out, or the players woudn't acknowledge me. I have a severe anxiety disorder, so vr is a really nice platform for me, but this was the worst possible place for that. 

The awful, terrible moderators were awful to me. Ignoring the screaming, and the slurs, and the flashing avatars, they came up to me instead, got in my face, called me obnoxious over a tiny laptop fan, and demanded I mute my microphone unless I'm talking (which i was talking). Embarassingly bad moderation team. 

You would think some updates would be made to improve this game, but there really hasn't been. It seems they're perfectly fine being what they've always been-- a subpar bootleg game that has zero optimization, terrible community, horrible safety settings that do not protect people, terrible moderation, terrible ui, terrible website design, terrible content, and I could go on and on. It can't stand on its own.. it is the toxic congegated sludge of "I  hate VRChat" despite having zero substance or even a good community to back it up.

It's just a bootleg that wont close shop because it's a shitty playground for the moderators.

TLDR:
*avatars are rigged weird and uncomfortably
*UI is awful
*terrible safety settings
*terrible optimization, it lags
*theres nothing to do because the game is so underdeveloped. It's at the bottom of the market for showing VR's potential.
*doesnt support quest which whipes out half the vr users right now
*Moderation team ignores toxicicity and embraces the worst parts of the metaverse
*the community is extremely toxic, the worst I've ever seen to the point I had to close dms because of the harassment i was getting from the playerbase, and makes the game unplayable (omg, worse than League!)

*instead of playing a shitty bootleg of VRChat that revolves around hating vrchat, just play vrchat.

Pretty much any claim about performance improvements as compared to competing platforms such as VRChat are demonstrably false with proper benchmarking. And no singular review could possibly cover the sheer amount of fundamental issues this platform faces with both management of its userbase and nasty clashes with pre-existing design philosophies.

Go play VRChat. It's where the people are, it's where the content is, it's where the social experiences are, it's where the proper UX is, and it's ultimately where you're going to have a better time.
112078771.developer_response:
Hi there, 

you are free to tell us about those fundamental issues by getting in touch via email to team@abinteractive.net or alternatively making a post in our community forums.

Saying claims (that are done by users, not us) are wrong is not reviewing the game, it is reviewing community rumors. 

When mentioning how much better said other platform is content and user base wise, you should also mention that the game has been in early access for a limited amount of time and the financial resources have been significantly lower. 

While we appreciate reviews that help us to improve the platform for those that genuinely like it or have a genuine interest, a review like this is nowhere close to be helpful.

110477353.review:
decided to give the game a try after a friend mentioned it to me.

One of the big things I heard and read in reviews is that this game run significantly better than vrchat.

I wholeheartedly disagree. The novelty of having worlds load while you explore another is nice but I wouldn't call it "faster".

Navigating the menu is a big jarring and somewhat cumbersome. Minor details about worlds take a bit too long to load in and the tagging system is seemingly under utilized.

Default controls are a bit bizarre too, specifically grabbing items is a chore. 
If items can be snapped directly into your hand it is unclear how to do so. I had a tendency to grab items from 5 feet away and have no way of getting them towards myself.

As many reviews have stated the game is absolutely desolate. I spent the majority of my time as the soul player until my final few minutes where a single person arrived.
The wasteland feel extends to created content as well. No active players results in no actively created content. 

I think the biggest thing that would get me back is some form of effort to draw in new users.
As for now I wouldn't recommend this over other "vr social" platforms.

If you have any suggestions feel free to post them on https://forums.abinteractive.net as well.
