it's good but im terrible at talking to random people.

anyway if you play vrchat, consider playing this. the devs seem to actually know what they're doing. and it needs more players.

(lots of words under here if you wanna read some stuff about the game)

there isn't too much content or worlds, but you gotta remember this game is new and unfinished. 

if you wanna see how many players are online, check out [strike] status.abinteractive.net. [/strike] https://steamdb.info/app/661130/graphs/

also, to the people who think this is a vrchat rip-off: it really isn't. in fact, vrchat took some UI FROM CHILLOUTVR.  
these devs actually listen to feedback, and of course the game is gonna have similar elements to vrchat, ITS A SIMILAR TYPE OF GAME. 

if you don't want to play this because of the low amount of players, i understand that, just consider that if you want this game to get more players, tell others to try it. its fine if they dont like it, since at least in this game the devs listen to feedback.

also, i get people dont like having to pay to upload more things, but, one, 10 is more than enough for a casual player, two, theres only 3 developers and they dont have the funding vrchat does, and three, its super cheap and a one time purchase, you can add way more things to avatars and there's props and other things, so i'd say its worth paying for. you seem content paying $10 a month for extra favorites. guess what, you can get like a thousand favorites here, for free :)

// LOTS OF TEXT HERE // 
Listing some things the game has.

- A tag system. (explaining more in the Settings part).

- Allows NSFW (in non-public worlds, of course). Unlike VRChat where you have to stay quiet about it, this game actually allows that stuff as long as you dont have it in public, and to even see it you have to download a free DLC and enable nsfw content in settings. yes, props too. you can have those types of props as far as i know.

- Developers listen to feedback.

- From my experience, the people that play are mostly nice. If they're mean to you, either you're being an asshole without realizing, you're playing at a bad time, or you just got unlucky, because some humans are just mean. it's expected for a social game.

- PROPS! Have you ever wanted the Force-A-Nature from hit game Team Fortress 2 to be usable in a social VR game? now you can! Wanna use the Meowmere from Terraria, or blind people with the Last Prism? You can! Want a cookie that you can eat? THAT TOO! Want a questionable item that needs that free DLC? Hell yeah you can. I love props. They're awesome. 

- Actually good settings! (this is a long one)
Graphics: Game running like shit? Lower the Resolution (you can go down to 320x200), turn off Bloom, lower Anti-Aliasing (or turn it off), you can even change your framerate cap! (60 to Unlimited).

Audio (bit buggy atm but thats unity): You can adjust the volume of World SFX, World BGM, Player Voices, Avatars, User Interface, Props, and the Video Players.
Input & Key Bindings: This one seems to be mostly for VR, so i dont understand it. You can increase mouse sensitivity here though.

Content Filter: You can choose whether you see everyone's Avatars, Your Friends' Avatars, or No-ones Avatars. You can select the Max Avatar Size (5 MB to Unlimited), and you can hide Avatars that have NSFW, Suggestive, Flashing Colors/Lights, Screen Effects, Extremely Bright, Gore/Death, Violence, Excessively Huge/Small, Horror, or Jumpscare.
Alternatively, You can remove individual components from Avatars, these options are Loud Audio, Long Range Audio, Music, Particle Systems, Dynamic Bones (collider is separate), cameras, windzones, and lights. 
there is a "Reload Avatars" button at the bottom of this page.

Prop Settings: Content filter for Props. This has every Content Filter setting except its for the props, and has additional options. Aside from just enabling/disabling props, you can toggle Particle Collision and Colliders, and toggle Touch Triggers.

Interactions: This is the Dynamic Bone section basically. you can choose who you can interact with and who can interact with you, as well as change whos interactions you see, and theres Collision Placement and Wind Interaction. 
under Player Physics Intercollision, you can toggle Particle Collision, Colliders, and Selfcollision. you can also enable touch triggers for player animator triggers.

Implementation: fairly small page. A few settings for Tobii Eye Tracking, BHaptics, and Vive Face tracking. 

Experimental: I dont get this one, really. it has "Always On Microphone Mode", as well as IK Settings, which are Plant Feet, Pin Hip to Tracker, Straighten Neck, Hip Shifting, and Pre Straighten Spine.

Support: this isn't really a setting, but, you can generate a support code for bug reports, which contains log files and some basic info like RAM, CPU, GPU, Unity Version, Game Version, OS, and a couple other things.

alright, im done with the settings part.

- Avatar/Prop sharing! Currently, as it's unfinished, the only way to get props is to have someone else share their props, but it's pretty easy so feel free to ask anyone who has a prop! though, only the uploader can share them of course. Same goes for Avatars i believe.

- Sub-Categories! for a lot of things! you can create up to 32 Sub-Cats for Friends, Groups (unfinished), Avatars, Worlds, and Props. Each. so i mean you have 32 for friends, and still have 32 for props. Currently, you can only edit these on the website, and this is where you enable content sharing (by default people cant just spam your props and avatar menus, you have to enable getting them from Friends or Everyone)

- Groups! These don't exist yet.

- The (unfinished) Website! it does things but i just wanna list it because you manage your uploaded content here. Apparently you can Transfer Avatar/World/Prop Ownership. You can also submit those for Publication, so for worlds, you can submit them and then they can be a public world anyone can join whenever. You can also manage what people shared with you, so if you got a prop you dont like you can remove it.

- You don't have to pay for a profile picture (looking at you and your dumb subscription, VRChat)

- You can see who is in a world before joining!

- NoClip!!! assuming the world allows it, which most do, enable Flight in the menu, or press 5 on the numpad. Enjoy.

- CALLS!! there's gonna be an upcoming feature where you can call people IN GAME.

RANDOM FUN FACTS //
- If you hold Alt, you can move your head around without turning your whole body.
- If you double-tap Alt, it sticks until you double-tap it again.
- Yen. I will not elaborate, you will learn what i mean.
- [strike]You can skip the intro by pressing space.[/strike] there is no more intro, i think.
- 0, 1, and 7 on the numpad. mess around with that.
- 5 on the numpad. have fun :3
- There is crouching and laying down. well, standing too.

if you want me to explain something then you should be able to comment, just remember i wont be 100% correct as im just someone who only has 50 hours in the game right now.

103703598.review: It's still growing, and not many of my friends have moved onto it from other social vr platforms, but it's still really good, in my humble opinion. Loading feels a bit more seamless than other platforms where they just drop you in a loading screen, or dump you in an empty space and slowly load/propagate objects and things, uploading avatars has felt fairly familiar compared to similar platforms, and the people behind all of it seem to be taking more player feedback than one of the other top contenders (read: taking any player feedback whatsoever is doing more so than VRChat has over the last few years). My only issue so far has been in the avatar that I uploaded looking fine in the Unity editor, then having janky looking fingers ingame, but I'm almost certain that's because of my model, and is probably already fixed by now, I just haven't tried uploading it again lately. Overall, I'd give my personal experiences with CVR, out of 10: 8/10 for the platform it's self, it's a lot better in some criteria compared to other platforms,  7/10 for my personal experiences inside CVR, and an 8/10 for usability of it's Unity editor creation kits, they're built similarly to things I already know how to use, and are easy to learn with their guides, and the few third party resources like videos I've watched to catch up.

The avatars seem to have more options on what to do with them and you are able to interact with other avatar's physics as well. TLDR: this is a fun game.

97680067.review:
Just over 1 year after my previous review, and in light of the sudden explosion of popularity CVR received, Before begining since some confusion still remains:
-The unlocked account only gives you unlimited upload slots, it is not necessary to upload at all.
-The free mature content DLC can be activated and deactivated from within steam.
I've decided to edit my review to better reflect the current state of the game.
I still Maintain that CVR is in a very unfinished state, however it has recently been making ground towards completion at an extremely fast pace. There are still game-wide issues, however they're actively being addressed by the developers who can be seen live testing and interacting with the community both in-game and in community outlets like their discord server. At the moment, instance stability seems to be their biggest issue.
I still maintain that CVR is a superior platform to VRChat, and now I have vindication in this appraisal in that it seems to be the first choice for people leaving the platform. The CCK has not aged as well as I'd expected, however it is far from obsolete in design by comparison. Aditionally, my comments on the platform's expandability and modularity also need update as both the CCK and the game client have been actively embracing new features in my time away.
Regarding my issues from the previous version of my review, I feel that while both are still an issue, they are being mended. the Chillout development team is pulling out all the stops to capitalize on the chance to garner new players and I applaud them for their efforts. In doing so, they are also now working on rectifying some issues I had with the UI, and implementing the "radial" menus from VRchat (hopefully as an option and not something that is just forced).

Conclusion:
CVR was, and definitely is now worth checking out. if you have any familiarity with VRC then you will adapt with fairly little effort. Performance by and large is fantastic. anyone around for the SDK2 days of VRChat should only spend minimal effort relearning the CCK, and the props system remains a unique, magical way to share content and experiences with other players. Please, PLEASE give Chillout VR a chance.

Many comments on my profile have reminded me to edit my once negative ChilloutVR review. Where I said:  "The nanosecond this game gets even a decent playerbase, I will hop ship from VRChat. I will also edit my review."

Yes. I would recommend you play ChilloutVR. 

But what I realized while playing ChilloutVR was that both it and Neos have a long way to go to topple VRChat. Just hopping ship isn't quite enough, VRChat is a ship that the community has been building for years, so many fantastic parts and memories are still left on that ship, and it'll take a while for the new ship to even compare.

Plus, the old ship had a much more intuitive control scheme and wheel layout that the captain is used to, and this is where this really shitty analogy breaks down. But whatever, review edited. ChilloutVR has a long way to go, but its on its way.

"It's such a shame, that I have to leave this review. This is, in literally every technical way possible, better than VRChat. Runs better, looks better, more interactivity/options, the works. 95187896.review:
While this game is currently in Early Access, its essentially VRChat on steroids with the devs ACTUALLY giving a sh*t about how it works. Sure, it still has its bugs and issues, but for something this early in development, it works better and run smoother than VRChat (Despite VRC being around longer.)

Pros:
~ ChilloutVR runs nicely and the way worlds are loaded is SO much better than VRChat. Instead of having to wait in a room with a loading screen, it just keeps you in the world you're currently in until the other world is loaded in before sending you there with a very smooth transition. 

~ Upload process for an avatar in Chillout is much faster than in VRChat with it not breaking as much during the process.

~ Allows NSFW content and avatars on their platform (which is really nice since it allows adults to be adults.)

~ No monthly subscription service for an enhanced users experience (Its a one time purchase enhancement instead.)

Cons:

~ Very few worlds to go visit and hang out with other users in.

~ Can only have three instances open at a time with no guide or explanation on how to terminate instances that are created.

~ Updates are pretty scarce with a lack of new content being added it, making this repetitive after a while.

In conclusion, while this is a really fun VR platform to hang out on, there really isn't a lot to do on here. After a while, its gets to be boring and with the lack of people that use it, you don't really get to meet new people at all. Plus, with the lack of updates and creators working on the platform to expand it and make it better, it really just ends up being pretty hollow. Maybe someday it'll be better but for now, its just not a VR socializing platform I want to spend my time on.

92454294.review: ChilloutVR is a platform that allows adults to be adults. Mature content is allowed, and properly filtered by the content filter system unlike another platform I will not mention here. I also had a bit more fun with Chillout than the other platform. One moment you're hanging out with people, the next moment, one person pulls out a bag of guns, and suddenly it's a game of deathmatch! Rocket launchers, miniguns, and so many other things. The guns are a part of the props system. If you want to make a rocket launcher that allows you to rocket jump, you can. If you want to make a working rocket, you can. I decided to make simpler props. I decided to make props of food, and other things. The CCK (content creation kit) you can get to upload avatars, worlds, and props is really easy to use. I figured out how to get my favorite avatar into Chillout with relative ease, and was even capable of adding custom animations with little to no hassle. Not only that, but the moderation is handled by human moderators instead of an AI that has full control over the platform. The AI present supposedly only calls in human moderators, nothing more. This means less errors, less unfair bans, and less stress. Since the AI is only there to alert a human moderator, spam reports by gangs are useless unless you are legitimately causing problems. This is NOT the case in the other platform. There, even if you do nothing wrong, use one of the stock avatars, and rarely talk, if a gang mass reports you, you can kiss your account goodbye. ChilloutVR overall is a much more professional and well made product, and I see the future of Chillout being bright. I'm also able to use my beeg marshmallow lady avatars with no ban. 90719064.review:
First of all im glad your reading this review ^^, it's shows my Perspective that is of someone that plays the game since the 29.3.2020.

ChilloutVR is as of the time right now (22.04.2021) more of an VR Social game then a VR Sandbox unlike they advertise. Mostly because it doesn't have any way to make custom game modes because it's missing a way of custom scripting they provide some scripts, for Avatars and Worlds which a few of them dont work fully and some dont work at all. The ones for Avatars are good enough to make simple and complex systems. For Worlds i sadly can't say the same its missing basic functions like proper Object Sync, as of the time right now Objects are only synced as long as you hold them in your hand. So throwing an object or pushing an object with your Avatar is not synced and only works locally. Next important feature would be the „Interactables“ its a script where you can define simple action like „On Interact“ which is clicking a collider. The problem is there's no syncing at all that means no way of syncing a Collider Click to every user in the Instance. A Great thing is that All Assets are Encrypted that means not every idiot can steel your Content which should be a standard but sadly its not for other competitors. They support some importand Unity features and even some cutome ones like „Dynamic bone“ „Final IK“ „Post Processing Stack 2.0“ „CTS 2019“ and a few more. Thats really helpful and makes creating content even without custom Scripting easy and beginner friendly. Everything in the Game itself is networked that means unlike other competitors there's not a lot of room for exploiting. Moderators are most of the time friendly and helpfull, Although i don't like the moderation personally which is something thats way to complex for this review tho. They are heading a great way, and have a lot of cool stuff planned like Official Game Modes, Official Event Planning and many more. They are open and the Community is mostly involved in testing and feedback. Im glad of supporting it since the first Day. If you ever meet me in the Game you can always ask me about all kinds of CVR related questions, i'm always glad to help people ^^

89385324.review:
ChilloutVR is a social VR game that is user friendly & easy to get started with, whilst still allowing powerful customization for those who aren't afraid of a little complexity. It has a decent funding model of the users paying for benefits such as dedicated servers, whilst still remaining free, so there's no worries of misaligned interests like with some investor money backed companies.

As an example of the sensible choices that CVR devs have made, they've allowed modding the game so that power users can customize their experience to their hearts content. Whilst VRC took the route of forcing EAC down everyone's throat as a stopgap fix that's by now already been bypassed by multiple different groups, CVR has actual proper client to server networking with the anticheat on the server side, unlike VRC. All whilst yes, still allowing mods that don't break their guidelines & rules.

There's now a thriving community of people & content on ChilloutVR too, so it's not like that's an excuse to not try it out anymore either. And it's way easier to get into than NeosVR, whilst still being developed & customizable.

88983060.review:
I'm going to write this with 200+ hours, a few badges from Closed Beta, and as someone who used to be a patron. I say this now because I would like to make clear my relationship with the community/devs and to make sure any form of bias is out of the way. This review will be split between the technical and community part, since those are generally the two defining factors in any sort of social game, whether it's VR or not.

Let's begin:

In the technical sense, CVR has proven itself to be the best suitable platform, between the dynamic bone interaction that is very easily configurable, to extra stuff such as props, advanced avatar settings, and the fancy little Gmod noclip flying. If you're working on something simple, or even working to convert your avatars, it is essentially the same as uploading to VRC with the 2.0 SDK. However major problems arise with more advanced efforts, as documentation is extremely limited and information about working with AAC or other such things is difficult to obtain. The UI hasn't noticeably improved, however it is dynamic and moddable so long as you understand how to mod it. As for optimization, the best thing I could ever really say is "Check the user content first." If you seem to have trouble outside the hub, it may not be the game itself, but rather an avatar or a world itself.

Community is more of an issue. While people for the most part of the player base are welcoming, there are symptoms of a plague that I tend to call the Alternative Community Paradox (ACP). Or just call it a razor or whatever you want.

ACP is an observation I have made across every social platform that has risen due to a piece of the mainline community breaking off to form what they find is objectively better. This community mainly comprises of users who are genuinely sick of the problems that were created by the authority of the platform which they left. Essentially a "blackjack and hookers" gig. However the attraction of a new platform with better features and a seemingly more welcoming atmosphere also invites malicious players who were banned from the platform previously. The combination of the veil over everyone's eyes and the toxicity of the outcasted users create an environment where a new user to the platform may perceive the alternative platform as completely toxic. Many examples include: 4chan/8chan, Twitter/Gab/Parlor/Mastodon, Furaffinity/too many to count.

The reason this is brought up is due to both personal interaction and from what I was informed. Players previously associated with "crasher gangs" and other toxic groups that have plagued the public space in VRChat have also been brought into CVR. While a few have given up the previous antics on VRC, there are others who are active in permeating issues, underlying rifts between the once small group of people.

Besides the issues at hand with the general drama groups, there are also certain names that have sucked up the social ranks to align themselves closer with moderation. This is obviously a disaster waiting to happen, and while I do not believe the moderators themselves are actively working against their own community, this poses a great risk to anyone who may assume that because someone doesn't enjoy them, they can work their way into convincing the moderator to remove them from the platform. Another review made on the store page brought this up, and while I don't personally know any details on this, I can only assume there is something amiss.

Furthermore, the most prevalent problems with CVR is ironically shared with VRC. From cliques who avoid interacting with others outside their group to the 'mirror zombie", CVR has unfortunately become nothing but another clubhouse. I'm optimistic that the devs will be able to eventually bring the promised game modes to the platform and really set out to expand themselves, but for now I unfortunately cannot recommend this game, at least to anyone who's had experience with previous VR social platforms.

Let me re-write my review in lieu of recent events. 

ChilloutVR was something of a sleeper agent for a very long time. Despite having a very small dev team with barely enough funds to keep the servers online, CVR pushed on for well over a year, crafting a better experience.

Then came the Exodus.

CVR became a safe haven for those displaced by a certain other game's terrible decisions. Servers were on fire from the massive increase in load, but nearly all I heard from the people was praise. They were shocked that an alternative this good had gone unnoticed by so many for so long, and many expressed wonder at why they hadn't made the change sooner. Suddenly the ABI team has resources, and many new devs have been hired on, and I for one cannot wait to see where CVR goes from here.

88238249.review:
Recently published on Steam, there it is. A game similar to how VR-Chat used to be. Actual conversations and memorable discussions, a game which feels welcoming and true. When you enter a lobby there is a much lesser chance of seeing people who are just glued to the mirror, captivated by their reflection in the mirror, dwelling what life could have been if they were born as their VR character? Of course you can take into consideration, that a game with a big player base can have an increasing amount of un-monitored and dubious behaviour and due to that, especially when the moderating tools were incapable of maintaining any form of law within public instances, many of the people would gravitate towards private instances and that mentality still remains even though things have changed. But that's VR-Chat. 

With ChillOut Vr being niche and possessing this long lost feeling of VR-Chat's legacy as well as a very responsive community which is always willing to aid in any regard, starting from dedicated community servers with a great collective of developers and content creators from which you can start to obtain your very first building blocks for Blender and Unity. Even though it may not have the same amount of community produced content, the potential is there and all that can come in the future, but it's up to you weather you are keen in taking the first steps forward on this platform. I think it is a perfect starting point for someone who has missed out on VR-Chat's ''Gold Era'' since late 2016 and instead should allow themselves to embrace this game which has many great features that VR-Chat tends to lack and build their own unique and memorable experience.

Hope this review helps to clarify previous concerns and will encourage you to try it out for yourself, thank you for reading!

87976312.review: The game itself had some promise with its basic optimization and customization features; however, the developers and moderators ruin the experience. While the game is in early access, it has lacked core features that the community has begged for since the launch of the early access (which was over a year ago while the developers have told users it’s only been a couple of months). Ignoring all the developmental issues of the game, the moderators’ attitude and actions towards players is appalling. I have not found a single moderator on their team that serves to help other players, and yet all of them have worked to hurt the community. From personal experience, moderators have banned, falsely accused, and revoked my access because of personal grudges against my character. They will even permanently ban users who politely question a ban like my friend did. They were incredibly petty from the beginning and would threaten to ban you for “harassment” if you stood behind a user. The game includes a simple system that I thought would be a good idea where you can select warnings for your avatar such as “flashing lights” or “loud audio”; however, they will completely ignore the warnings and tell you to delete your avatar if they dislike it. Overall, I’d say a game that would have potential if it were a different team.

[i]This is my opinion, see for yourself if you agree or not[/i]

This game has a lot of potential in the state it's now, it's user friendly and its easy to learn.

I already have send feedback on everything I have seen, since that helps the game improve over time.

87253680.review: Taking into consideration that this is still in beta, it has a lot of promise. There are quality of life features that are small but major improvements over VRChat, However there are other features that are left to be desired. Not sure what exactly the difference is in terms of code and unity versions, but VRChat natively supports finger tracking provided by the index knuckle controllers while chilloutvr does not. Going from having individual fingers to having a set number of gestures is a little jarring when your used to a more immersive experience. Going along those lines, I also noticed that while my avatars visemes seem to register on other peoples screens, I could not see my mouth moving in mirrors. 87196152.review:
[h1]My formal recommendation for this title:[/h1]
Piss around with it for a bit and see what it's like. Wait until proper updates for formal use (such as uploading content). For all intents and purposes, this game is still a prototype and so many components are either missing or only implemented at their most simplistic level. The roadmap is very straightforward and their intent is clear as daylight.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- It's not VRC.
- The ToS accommodate for mods!
- [i]Orders of magnitude more control over avatar features[/i] - you can go down to targeting avatars by specific attributes such as long range vs short range audio, the type and nature of any effects (e.g. graphic, flashy, etc.), and much much more. There's a whole list you can filter through as opposed to the shoddy 5 options offered by VRC's "Safety Settings".
- Far more versatile content. Avatars can have configurations to alter their appearance on the fly without the need for mods. They can also spawn props and items. The content filter allows you to disable this for avatars if you want, so when the inevitable joke avatars run rampant, it's easy to disable. Ever wanted your avatar's weapon to be an actual holdable weapon that you can let other people mess with on your own accord? Now you can! Have fun.
- Your world doesn't sit in [strike]community labs[/strike] limbo for a year before it gets approval.
- More rigorous avatar approval process that prevents the overly intrusive avatars and that blatantly offensive content you tend to see in VRC, or at the very least requires them to be appropriately tagged so that the verbose limit system can be used properly. Failure to tag avatars properly based on the features they have is grounds for its removal or declination.
- Native FBT support.
- Native Vive adv. tracking support.
- Native bHaptics implementation, with the ability to whitelist / blacklist people or groups in terms of who can trigger it.
- Comes with noclip for worlds that have it enabled.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- It's early in development and it shows. If you have patience for early titles, please do play this! It's enough to work with and just needs a bigger community.
- Small team gives it a pretty big case of [i][url="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0d6yBHDvKUw"]These Things, They Take Time[/url][/i] (though they are working very hard towards the end goal and it is promising).
- UI is kind of bleh (on the roadmap to be fixed within the year).
- Takes some getting used to, the controls are odd. It's not terrible but you're gonna have some habits to break.

86851343.review:
Doesn't contain some key features that the only other comparable game (VRChat) has currently.

*No avatar cloning

At the minute, there are no public avatars or avatar pedestals, which can be frustrating for more casual VRC players who don't create their own avatars in Unity. For anyone who does create their own VRC models, it is no issue to port your avatar over. There is a way to share avatars, but it requires giving someone an upload key. So if you don't know someone willing to do so, you're out of luck.

*UI is not as easy-flowing

You have to go through about 3+(?) clicks in-order to hide a specific person's avatar. Kind of annoying, but it is part of a new game coming out. The menu in this game is fixed, which is nice! You can lay down and use it easily. However, there is nothing like the quick menu in this game, requiring you to open the fixed, opaque menu. 

*No [b]customizable[/b] safety settings

As far as I could tell, the customizability for safety settings doesn't seem to be in the game yet. Meaning, it is either full avatar on or full avatar off. Not having an option for shaders off and stuff really sucks, but I assume something like that will be implemented later.

*No Friend Search (this'll definitely be implemented later so)

*Unlocked account needed to upload more than 10 avatars

This is an inevitably for a new game. VRChat started on local server hosting, you used to have to connect with IPs. I believe they only moved towards dedicated servers/instances like today once they gained some funding from HTC(?). This is excusable, but definitely is something that I wanna note.

Oh yeah, all servers are European, so that is a good reason to try the game if you're European.

*No answer to Udon currently, but Newton seems interesting

"using our in-house scripting toolkit "Newton" (not yet available). This way we allow creators to create game modes like Trouble in Terrorist town, various kinds of coop tower defense games or even MMORPGs in ChilloutVR"

I'd infer from this that maybe a save system of some kind will be possible in Newton? Mainly the line of "MMORPGs" is what gives me that impression. Currently, the only way to save in Udon would be a password system or a code that is auto-generated that can be copy and pasted. If Newton could have a save feature of some kind, it'd give it a massive edge over Udon. 

========

I had the game while it was in early alpha and tried it a few times with a single friend, which of course isn't a great metric. I am not a Unity man myself so I was basically just looking at a growing game. Once the game released on steam, I hopped on with two other friends to try the game out for a bit. We joked that this game's community would just be a refuge for people banned from VRChat, especially during the beginning of CVR. As expected, in a game where you can create custom content, we ended up getting crashed. Due to the game's small community, this will definitely be an issue, as it is much harder to avoid toxic people since there are only 100+ players present at a time. However, the nice people you meet are definitely genuine in this game and want to see it grow. 

The game feels as if its in an awkward middle-ground between VRChat and NeosVR. That mainly just comes down to avatars not being easily shareable I think. The main thing the game does seem to offer at the minute is the prop system. I'm not sure how it works, but it seems similar to spawning in an item wherever you want in any world. It also has the ability for you to interact with other people's dynamic bones without the use of a modded client. I personally do not care at all for that feature, but some people seem to love it.

However, if you're willing to help build a community, then you'll enjoy CVR.

86829950.review:
After 1000 hrs on the old Launcher and approaching 1000 hrs after the VRChat migrations. Here is what I can say about ChilloutVR.

It's not comparable to VRChat, this is a platform to make things outside the SocialVR aspects. Here are the pros and Cons.

Pros:
This team is highly focused on Security and end user experience. Everything added is heavily tested for security exploits before its even available in testing/experimental branches.

Example content is available in the Content Creation Kit (CCK). You rarely have to look for community prefabs in order to make content here, and modules are available for various whitelisted unity packages like Magica Cloth simulations.

There are many and I mean MANY safety features ranging from whether you want lights on people or down to limiting polygon counts on meshes.

Modding the game is safer than ever with a dedicated modding network for mods to use. No more hosted networks from mod authors, the game servers handle it all and keeps the game and users secured.

Cons:
The game has a bad habit of users from other platforms coming in to spread misinformation. The converter tools that people released are made from users who don't play the game and leads users into a bad experience.

Avatar interactions are currently limited to the Pointer and Trigger system while it is very versatile, you cannot currently grab/pull on avatar bones. This may change in the future.

Final thoughts, all and all this is a great platform for creators and has excellent security for end users. I welcome everyone to discuss and ask questions in the community and I highly recommend talking to members of the team and community guides. They will have the most reliable source of info about the game.

86769938.review:
What this game, and its competitors do, is ingenious in that the players create all the content.

For the players to create the content, they first need to learn how to do so.

The documentation of its biggest competitor is outdated and lackluster. I spent months writing a compendium for it because the information the devs offered wasn't great and certainly wasn't enough.

CVR really lacks content at the moment. It would be a huge advantage over its biggest competitor if it had a complete documentation so that users interested in uploading avatars and worlds could do so easily and without confusion.

As of right now, the game has come out of alpha and into early access. On the official documentation, there is a page for avatars, which is empty, and a category on the sidebar for worlds, which doesn't have a single page.

Also, I tried the game in alpha over the summer, and it said not to criticize the game because it was still in development. Seriously? Instead of say, linking to a page to report bugs or request features? Shows a lack of confidence in the product to me.

I see immense revolutionary potential in social VR, one that transform the way many of us live. I am disappointed to see the devs of these social VR platforms, the ones actually in control of its future do not share that foresight nor vision.

I've heard many long time users of CVR's rival claiming that it's an upgrade, saying it cares about the community, hoping for a better platform (entirely understandable considering the alternative). But I don't see it that way. I only see a clone. And I am immensely disappointed, because it could have been so much more.

P.S.: CVR will never overtake it's biggest competitor without Quest support. I say this as a PC VR user who sees that the Quest series is by far the most popular headset (we don't count PSVR) and it will only continue to become more and more dominant. Yes many social VR users on Quest are far too young and Facebook and those respective platforms need to make it clear that these are mature spaces. I am also frightened by the potential of a Facebook VR monopoly, but I still need to acknowledge the trend that, without Quest support, a VR app is severely limiting its audience and potential for growth.

86646978.review:
I just want to start off by stating the obvious, that this game is still in the very early stages of development.  

At the time of this review, players are not able to share their avatars, nor are there any worlds in-game that have avatars for the player to acquire.  That being said, the game has a lot of features that are quite different than other titles, such as VRChat.   The first thing I noticed was that full body tracking is definitely really nice.  They also have options to lock the neck or spine if you want a more rigid full body tracking.  Having it set to default allows dancers to even perform body-rolls and other smooth looking dance moves that other VR titles may not quite allow as well.

Another nice feature is that you can set your preferences to filter Not Safe For Work avatars and worlds.  This means that you can turn off avatars that are flagged correctly by users, or have them always visible.   This is a great feature, especially for streamers. 

If you know how to import avatars into VRChat, then you will be fine with doing the same with ChilloutVR.  Basically, Chillout has most of the features of Avatar 2.0, with a few nice additions.  There are some good tutorial videos of these features on YouTube if you want to search for those.  There will be Avatar 3.0 type support coming in the future as well.   The Devs update the game regularly with solid changelists and development tracks.

This game will just keep getting better.  I hope to see you all in there sometime!

Is still a bit early and this review may change in the future depending how the development team and moderators act with the community and the development of the game itself. I always try to be as neutral as possible at my reviews so what i'm about to give to you is an idea of the good and bad stuff of this game. Also on most of my reviews i try to put the good and bad point lined up so is easier to jump between point and look both sides of the coin when is about specific things (Note: If there is something good/bad writed, but nothing on the oposite side it means that is perfect the way it is for me).
And finally before starting the review i gotta point that comparing this game to VRChat is neccessary as it has the potential to become the main competitor with it. So on this review there is gonna be lots of comparation with VRC.
Anyway let's do this:

The good stuff:
-Menu and configuration: As a VRChat player, because been honest most of the players here came form VRChat, i feel comfortable enough with the many options that i cna find at the menu. Be able to configurate my gameplay is important when is about virtual reality and ChilloutVR gives you a lot of freedom on this way.
-Worlds and Transitions: The game is well optimized when we are talking about the current worlds in the game, i got a few more FPS than at VRChat which i deeply thank for. Also is really interesting to stick aroudn and interact for a bit longer on the world where you are while the next one is loading, this was a brilliant idea, 10/10.
-Avatars and their system: Is really good and easy the way it works for uploading avatars to your account (if you were a content creator like at VRChat). It need a few more tutorial when is about adding animations into your avatars, but that's probably me because i haven't learn yet how to do them.
The idea of spam Prop swhich your friends or even strangers can use is amazing. As the system with the colliders and dynamic bones by default.
-Social Experience: Right nwo there are not that many players, around 100-150 everyday and sometimes reaching 200. This makes easier to be friendly with people becuase at the end of the day you know most of the players and is easy to get close to them and talk. Anyway making new friends has been relatively easy for me so far.
-Payment: Is free

The bad Stuff:
-Menu and Configuration: For some people it can be way to conplicate and even if it isn't you gotta spend a few long minutes investigating to fully figure out how it works. I would recomend to make it, not simpler, but easier to look at for the players.
Also you ar enot able to hide the HUD (it gives you the option, but it doesn't work for now)
-Worlds and Transitions: Not be able to see how heavy a world is before joinning is a thing that can scare some of the users of CVR. It's true that the game has no loading screen and you can stick for a bit longer with your friend at the current world before jumping to the next one, but a "% loading bar" would be good so we can cancel the jumping if the world is gonna be way to heavy or even give us those seconds to say "good-bye" to our friends before leaving that world.
-Avatars and their system: It need a few tutorials for those who wanna learn how to upload custom avatars. The prop spaming can lag a bit or a lot of you don't add a limit of props to spam. The loading of avatars works fast, but currently at VRChat is faster and way less laggy.
-Social Experience: You mist your friends at VRChat and gotta put more effort into this game if you wanna drag them form there, because eventually players who give a try to this game will miss the old friends playing VRChat and they will come back. I like the game, but i'm starting to think about going back sometimes into VRChat just to be with them. This is probably the biggest problem of ChilloutVR right now.
-Payment: Is free unless you are a content creator, because if you wanna upload you creations you are gonna need to pay.

86400529.review:
Been playing since the closed alpha. Even all the way back then, this game has been exceptionally stable. It has better performance than probably any other VR game I've played; even when I had a first-generation Oculus Quest linked up with a 2.0 cable with my RX 580 struggling to keep most VR games above ~20 FPS, this game ran smoothly, and now that I have a half-decent rig it runs like a dream.

You might ask why I'm focusing so much on the performance. Well, this is a multiplayer VR game. If the performance isn't smooth, you simply cannot interact with other players in the same way you can in real life or non-VR games. Only if a VR game is properly optimized can you comfortably play VR, as otherwise you get motion sickness, your hands can't interact with things properly, the other players might rubberband or freeze up, etc. This is one of the biggest problems with this game's biggest competitor, VRChat, which constantly lags, locks up, or otherwise performs poorly, even on the best of specs. To me, currently, this is the main strength of ChilloutVR. It has been rigorously tested and optimized to ensure some of the smoothest gameplay of any VR game I've played.

There are some things ChilloutVR is currently lacking, but they are primarily due to the game's early access state. For one, it doesn't have anywhere near the playerbase nor user-generated content of even the smallest of the other VR chatrooms. There are only a handful of avatars around, and just a couple of worlds to be in, and those worlds nearly always seem to be empty. But don't get me wrong, this game isn't dead; rather, it hasn't been born yet. There hasn't been some mass exodus of players or anything, they just aren't here yet, and I expect that to change quickly once this game leaves early access. The playerbase isn't the only problem, though. The new player experience is quite barren, with no real tutorials of any kind, so if you haven't played similar games you'll be totally lost trying to figure out the menus and controls (and even with that experience, it still takes a while to get used to this game's menu). But this is a sentiment that can be seen frequently in other reviews, and I expect this to change before the game leaves Early Access, as these developers are incredibly responsive (I've even had a chat with them once or twice, they are quite polite).

So, should you get this game? I'd say go for it. If you want to see what the next frontier is for infinitely-evolving, player-driven multiplayer VR, come right in. But right now, this frontier is vacant, save for a few tents. If you feel like jumping in anyways, welcome! The data you generate will be crucial to testing and improving this game, especially if you join the Discord and give feedback there. If you want a more complete, polished experience, come back soon! I'm not going to lie to you, this game is not complete or polished. That's why it's in early access. But mark my words, it will be. And when it is, I truly believe this will be the greatest, most refined multiplayer VR game out there.

86400386.review:
Ok so first off, is this better than VRChat? In my opinion, no. But it is definitely the closest thing VRChat has had to competition in a long time, and it's clear a lot of work was put into it, with a clear view of what it should be (Which, frankly is "VRChat but with some changes")

The best thing about this game is the pre-loading of worlds and the seamless transitions to them. VRChat needs this. Most other things are exactly as they are in VRChat. Its impressive they were able to create so much so fast, but its also clear that being able to start with VRChat as a finished product to learn from drastically shaped their view and sped up their development. But that's kinda how this stuff works.  They've legitimately added some cool stuff to that (Inter-player physics, seamless world transitions, pre-loading, a cleaner and more responsive UI... most of the time) But overall VRChat has them beat. Udon, Avatar 3.0, and just the sheer level of content, gameplay, and players in VRChat.

I will definitely be keeping an eye on this project and visit often. I think the worst thing about it at the moment is all the people in the game seem like its their duty to tell you how bad VRChat and their devs are, and how much better ChilloutVR is.  Tons of people who got banned from VRChat (for good reason) existing solely to be anti-VRChat. It's really disappointing and I think they need to... Chillout? and just enjoy the fact that they have a cool platform that is likely to become a major shaper in Social VR as a whole (and maybe spark some changes in VRChat for the better too, yay competition!).

86390794.review:
[h1]This is coming from a VRChat user who's played for over 500 hours, fyi (on Oculus & Steam).[/h1]

[h1]Edit 1 (around 1pm, 11/Feb/21)[/h1]
I should've mentioned, but I will continue giving this game a try. Maybe I'll end up liking it - at the time of this edit, I am looking at ChilloutVR's SDK for avatar creation, I loaded up the pre-built Rexouium CVR package and I'm just exploring it and trying to compare it to VRChat's SDK3.0. I quite like the fact it allows you to not only set a view position, but also a voice position, I had never thought of that but it's just extra detail that I can appreciate.
The login process into the CVR SDK requires a special key from your account from their website, which is just an extra safety measure I'll presume. So far I like it.

[h1]Edit 2 (1:32am, 12/Feb/21)[/h1]
I've given the game a second try, this time with my own avatar uploaded and even met a friend accidentally in a random world. I have to say, my opinions have changed. I'll update the review tomorrow, as it's late right now.

[h1][hr]The original review[/hr][/h1]

Firstly, this game [i]needs[/i] a better tutorial. The default hub world with some signs explaining basic things was not helpful to me. I was clueless playing for basically the past 2 hours playing the game, and quite frankly, still am. This game makes no effort to explain how to get avatars, for example. I still am the default Kyle robot (not using the other 2 default ones, as they don't work as well with full-body).
I know I can upload my own avatars, and most likely will, but as a noob to the game I would've at least liked to explore it for the first time in something other than the default avatars.
I don't think there is any avatar cloning like VRChat, and there was no 'loading' avatar either - people would literally stay invisible until their avatar loaded in. 

Thankfully, full-body tracking is very well supported, that worked instantly when I loaded into the game for the first time. Even has some options such as 'Pre-straighten spine' which I find useful for the quality of my tracking, which are not present in VRChat. There was no weird viewpoint drift either as is generally present with VRChat full-body. Still, I would much rather prefer it if the avatar would move according to your head's position, instead of being stationary.

The menu is also freezed into the world when you open it. When you press the buttons on it, it seems to only register that something is pressed when you [i]firmly[/i] press down on your trigger, either that or it failed to register the clicks half the time (my controllers are not the issue). The menu is less than pleasant, it will take up most of your vision when you open it and the fact you can't move it make it more annoying, I would much rather prefer a menu stuck to the hand like in VRChat instead.

(so, why am I comparing this to VRChat so much? Well, as I've seen being said, this has the 'potential' to overtake VRChat. If it's supposed to have the potential for that, then it has to be [i]better[/i] than VRChat, does it not?)

One feature that surprised me was, when I took off my headset, I found out that I could still control the game & walk around as if I was in desktop mode - for the most part. Camera movement seemed to be stuck to just left/right (no up/down), and I don't think I could open my menu either. Still though, it's a cool feature that definitely gets an up over VRChat, but not sure how useful it'd be in its current state.

I have yet to try the ChilloutVR SDK for avatar creation, so I can't compare that to VRChat's (if I did, I would compare it to VRChat's sdk3.0).

A feature I saw that I was also unable to figure out how to do was Props. You can spawn your own props in the game - at least if you know how to, I guess? There's no props you can spawn by default, and you can't clone props from the world to your list or anything like that (yet again, the game makes no effort to explain the prop system to you). This is actually something NeosVR does better. In NeosVR, by default you start with a few 'folders', containing props inside. To get more folders, you can ask people to share more folders with you, obviously containing more props and even sub-folders. Unless ChilloutVR already does this (as I said, the game doesn't explain this stuff to you, so I'm still clueless), I think that NeosVR can also be an inspiration point. 

[h1]Overall?[/h1]
I don't get how this is considered a 'VRChat killer', at least [i]not in its current state.[/i] The game does very little to incentivise me to move over to it from VRChat, and with the game's poor tutorial, I was still left clueless on many of the game's mechanics even after nearly 2 hours. I wanted to give it a proper try, I really did, I could've left in the first 30 but I didn't; I tried to like this game, as I heard the hype over it and its 'potential' to kill VRChat, but I ended up leaving disappointed. 

[b]If you're looking for a game like this where you can meet people and hang out, go play VRChat instead, or even NeosVR.[/b]
Come back to this game at a later date. I do not recommend the game in its current state.
86390794.developer_response:
Hi there and thank you for your feedback, we have just launched into early access with the intention to improve our game along with user feedback. We know that better documentation is more than necessary and we are working on that part. 

If you have any suggestions or feedback you want to submit to us directly, you are free to mail us at team@abinteractive.net and we will get back to you as soon as we can.

I've been playing ChilloutVR Since April and I gotta say, it's amazing thus far. Like any game it has a lot of things that need fixing and work, but that's why it's in early access. 

Performence is amazing, hands down. I have seen some reviews claiming otherwise but with a RTX 2070 and an i7 8900k I get 144fps 144hz gameplay that's smoother than VRChat has ever been.

I also make a lot of content for games like these, creating worlds and avatars is very fun! I quite enjoy the way the SDK (CCK) is laid out. Unlike other SocialVR platforms, CVR uses the latest version of Unity, which is a huge plus! 

The UI is my main gripe with this game, it feels super clunky and i'm sure many reviews mention it. This will be changed in future releases though and I will update my review accordingly, as I am an active player. 

This game has a lot of promise! They promote free speech, allow NSFW content, and want people to be creative. The devs are great people who have monetized the game in a fair way. No subscription required. Chillout has a ton of potential, the ability to join a lobby with almost 100 people in it and maintain 60fps whilst displaying everyones avatar is astounding. 

Keep it up guys, I'm glad to be a part of this.

1. Run/Start the game.
2. Open sound settings in windows.
3. Go to Advanced sound options and click the "App volume device preferences".
4. Look for the game in there and then change the "output" and "input" device for the program / game to your headset.
5. Close the game and Run/Start the game again

86310483.review:
This is more of a sandbox game with an emphasis on user generated content, rather than a "VRChat Clone" like what many might say to lead you here, while many ideas may be similar this is a much different game than others may lead you to believe. It's something I've come to really learn with my time with this game and what I think has really kept me playing this over other options.

A lot of people come into or came into ChilloutVR with the misconception that it's "just a vrchat clone" and while it has a lot of similar elements that make it viable in function as an alternative this is a lot more of a sandbox. Less of a "twitter but vr" or "discord but vr" and more of a "gmod but vr", at least early gmod before there was other gamemodes. Joining public lobbies can end up being very different from one another, people just hanging out with a spawned in video player listening to music or watching videos, and absolute chaos (the fun kind) of spawned in cars, memes, escalators, toy tanks, helicopters, all sorts of wacky non-sense all facilitated by the ability to upload user-generated content.

I must iterate that due to this more niche angle (it's more of a sandbox) and it's early stages in development it comes with a number of things that make it rough to get into as a new user, there's a lot of tinkering with settings that you need to do before you have things setup to your liking, I'm told this is something they're wanting to look into at some point in the future.

86304845.review: ChilloutVR on PC is basically a combination between the good side of GMod and the good side of VRChat as of currently writing this..

86304085.review:
Well first the most important part on this review and everyone wants to know... is ChilloutVR a perfect product? No its not its beta and early access for a very good reason. 

And now that we are on it lets talk about the bad stuff first even though right now this is a more informative thing so people trying CVR know what they get into. World building is prolly the most sore spot due the proper scripting API not being finalized and released yet. And just having entered beta there is glitches and annoyances to be expected. Also the UI is still pretty much a draft and will get a major rework soon, its not bad and straightforward enough but still neither ergonomic nor pretty.

And now lets go to the nice stuff. FPS, FPS and even more FPS, even now CVR is super optimized already and runs super smooth even on pretty weak PCs, unless someone uses a REALLY badly done avatar or world. A filled instance and you still have a bloody good time. CVR is unlike a certain other platform properly multi threaded and makes use of your modern CPU to full extend.  

As the time of writing CVR only crashed ONE time and that was the Steam release day. Also the CCK you need to create content for CVR is super easy to use, quick and very clearly structured, you made stuff in Unity before you feel right at home. Also something IMPORTANT to know for creators here, your hard work gets encrypted on the server and is encrypted in the local cache so ripping is very VERY hard, if possible at all right now.

Avatars are bloody amazing you can make them simple or use advanced avatar settings that adds a lot interactivity, a boopable nose, a cellphone that controls your avatar you think about it you can prolly do it.

CVR has props, you have a bare bones world that needs more stuff you can add it everywhere any time and like avatars you can make them anything you want, the cake has not to be a lie anymore. And once scripting is out maybe a chess game in a swimming pool? Why not.

Also some last icing on the top that never ends, intractable dynamic bones (touch peoples hair), the ability to fly everywhere (world creators will be able to turn this off to prevent cheating in games later), avatar colliders for example like being able to stand on someones hand if they are either really huge or you very very small, and user pictures in your name tag that wont cost anything extra.

Another thing is world loading, you can preload worlds you know you want to visit a certain time later, preload it in the backround and have it ready once you go. And world loading is seamless you stay in your current world until the other world is loaded and not being stuck in the loading screen for ages if your connection is not the most quick one.

And before I forget two last things, while your basic account is a bit restricted a ONE time fee and you get everything no monthly recurring fee at all. 

And once the modding API is done, client modding is actually encouraged and welcomed no banhammer for just trying todo something good or enrich the game client.

Will update this review as the game grows.

I just spent about 4 hours in this game and its pretty ok so far, here's some pros and cons

PROS:
*Has some better avatar functions such as spawning in objects, customization, etc.
*you have the ability to fly
*the game feels a bit cleaner than vrchat
*faster world load times
*easier to calibrate fullbody tracking

CONS:
*The menu is very buggy, it takes 5-7 attempts to press buttons sometimes
*there's currently no way to get custom avatars in game other than uploading to unity
*there's a limited selection of worlds at the moment
*it's hard to find worlds with any people

Overall this is a pretty good game, it's just in it's early stages. Most, if not all issues i have with it will be fixed as updates come. I can genuinely see this becoming a vrchat competitor, but it will take a bit of time before it reaches that point.

86299469.review:
[h1] I've been dipping in and out of this community since early alpha. Nice people, but I never made any connections. That means this review is out of pure honesty, and a non-biased standpoint. [/h1]

[b] TL;DR: It's going to take some time to evolve, but it is 100% worth it. At a fundamental level, this is the best social VR application. [/b]

     This social application is going to provide a lot more than VRChat soon, and there will be a big shift in how social VR is perceived. I've had some friends join this game just to test FBT (Full-Body Tracking) as well as tested it with a Kinect (v2), and it seems to perform better than NeosVR and VRChat. On top of this, it actually multi-threads, so Ryzen and Intel CPUs are essentially equal and both get a performance boost.
     Another big thing is "Unlocked Accounts". I understand the gross idea of making people pay to create content, but it cuts down on spam content, such as avatar rips, crashers, etc. that can make it into the game. Even if people are able to pay the $7 USD, there's a lot more safety settings then VRChat has to offer right now. You can toggle Gore, NSFW, Extremely Large/Small, Flashing lights, etc on both avatars and props. It's something I've wanted for the longest time and I finally found it. After all, that $7 helps the developers pay for server capacity and grow the community. and its the price of a fucking BURGER for god's sake. Help em out x)
     So far, with the CCK (Content Creation Kit), It's super easy. It's just like making VRChat content except you won't need that separate SDK for worlds and avatars. As of 2021/02/09, it uses Unity 2019.4.13f1, which is a huge upgrade from the basic 2018.4.20f1 or 2017.4.39f1 versions that people used to use. Simply a better layout, dark theme by default, new icons for all your assets; it just makes everything easier: and while I know that's on Unity, it was a pleasure that the developers chose the 2019.4.13f1 version over the others.

This game has a lot of true potential in it. And I can't wait for it to be a true competitor to VRChat/RecRoom/NeosVR. and now i want a burger, shit.

86299118.review:
Background - 4000+ Hours in VRC - 3 in CVR
Hardware - Index w/ FBT on a RTX 3090

I plan on keeping an eye on CVR.  Being a avid VRChat player I'm pretty familiar with all of the ins-and-outs of VRC, what it's good at and what it isn’t.  I’ve just started messing around in CVR and would like to give my first impressions.  

I won't mention anything about the playable content of CVR compared to VRC because that's pointless.  CVR was just released...VRC has been out for years.  Given enough time though, I believe the CVR platform has the capability and functionality to make better and more enjoyable content in the long run.

My immediate first impressions:

Visually the game seemed more vibrant, detailed, and smoother than VRC even in the starting world.  This didn't seem to be a content observation but a technical one.  It just seemed....more crisp and detailed.  Objects in the world interacted more realistically IMO.

After messing around with unity and the CVR SDK I managed to get my personal avatar loaded and joined a few familiar worlds solo.  Performance overall appeared better than in VRC counterparts. 

The IK for FBT appears to be more sensitive and responsive, however still needs a bit of work.  Calibrating took a bit for me to get everything moving right, but still some movements were still a little wonky, most notably the hip/chest movement for me.  But overall, still better FBT tracking/movement in comparison to VRC IMO.

Joined a world with 15 other people and this is where I noticed a fairly large drop in performance.  But nothing that was unexpected.  After turning off some settings, or setting them to friends only, performance returned.  It should be noted that performance issue, just like in VRC, are the majority of the time due to user created content and it's optimization, not the platform.  However, having said that, I can say that given an apples-to-apples situation, I am certain that CVR would outperform, FPS wise, VRC handily.

In short, CVR could be the game that might be the next stepping stone in the social VR experience journey.  Only time will tell, but it's definitely worth taking a look into if that's your thing.

86287763.review:
Been a part of ChilloutVR (CVR) since Closed Alpha, and have watched the game grow and improve over it's time, and I must say I am thoroughly impressed with what the Devs have done in such a short amount of time!

Comparing CVR to it's main competitor, there is a noticeable improvement of performance, and native features. To give a couple of examples, global dynamic bone interactions with other players, and a flight mode - both of which you would need to use mods to achieve the same result with the competitor. Features for the creative mind are also impressive, and included natively such as particle force fields and the props system, which allows users to globally spawn items they've created, and all users can interact with them. You can see these features showcased in the trailer.

Overall, I am very happy spending my time over the past year with CVR, the community, and the rest of the team. Feedback is listened to very carefully, and acted upon very quickly. Bugs that are reported by the community are also noted by the Devs, and fixed within a relatively short timeframe - bear in mind there are only 2 Developers working on the game, so it's really impressive what they've done in such a short space of time! I am am looking forward to what the future of ChilloutVR will bring! <3

86270689.review:
[h1][b]Addressing the misinformation[/b][/h1]
Unfortunately many people from different platforms really don't want ChilloutVR to succeed and in order to do that a lot of misinformation about the game is being spread around. If you will hear someone speak badly about ChilloutVR please don't listen to them and try the game out yourself, even if it's your friends.
[strike][u]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/u][/strike]
[b]Common misinformation consists of but is not limited to:[/b]
[i][quote]"ChilloutVR is just a ripoff / a clone of VRChat"[/quote][/i]
You could very well say that VRChat is a ripoff of Second Life. It's like comparing apples and pears. Yes there are some similarities between the two but ChilloutVR is its own product bringing revolutionary stuff to the market.
[strike][u]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/u][/strike]
[i][quote]"You have to pay to play / pay to upload"[/quote][/i]
ChilloutVR is absolutely free to play. When it comes to uploading you have 10 slots for avatars, 10 for worlds and 10 for props. You can remove your assets or overwrite them by reusing the GUIDs. Other than that when it comes to public avatars there are [b]NO FAVORITE LIMITS[/b]. If you want to upload for example more than 10 avatars you need to purchase an unlocked account which is a [b]ONE TIME PAYMENT[/b] of $8. Unlocked account gives you [b]UNLIMITED UPLOAD SLOTS[/b] and helps cover the storage costs.
[strike][u]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/u][/strike]
[i][quote]"The game supports ripping and crashers"[/quote][/i]
This one couldn't be further from the truth. The game has completely secure backend with proper authorization, your assets are encrypted, cache bundles are incomplete therefore preventing people from extracting anything of use from them. There are several more layers of security which are not public. Of course same thing applies to crasher avatars. The devs are constantly expanding the anti crasher system which includes component analysis as well as shader analysis. In the future you won't even be able to upload crashers to the game.
[strike][u]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/u][/strike]
[i][quote]"The devs are incompetent"[/quote][/i]
To give a bit of insight on this. This mostly comes from people coming from VRChat. VRChat has been first published in 2014 and looked like this:
[spoiler]https://twitter.com/VRChat/status/1350271716518481920?s=20[/spoiler]
It has been [b]in development for 7 years now (4 years in early access on Steam)[/b] and the game is still riddled with stability issues, no security and an abundance of bugs. Not to mention the fact that [b]VRChat has about 20 developers and 15+ million dollars in investments[/b].
ChilloutVR has been in development for [b]not even 2 years[/b] (company founded mid 2019) and the team consists of [b]ONLY 2 DEVELOPERS[/b] (who with the help of the community are funding the game) and has just been released into early access on steam yet many features already exceed what VRChat is capable of.
[strike][u]-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[/u][/strike]
[i][quote]"The staff is rude and power hungry"[/quote][/i]
Once again absolutely not true. The staff is incredibly nice and always willing to help everyone. The only people who are claiming the above are those who were behaving in a toxic way, harassing newcomers in public instances, playing ear rape over their microphones, saying profanities out loud and got banned by the moderation team.

[h1][b]The actual review[/b][/h1]
The game has the potential to be absolutely the best. Many of the features already completely outclass the competition and many more are under development. Yes the game sure is rough around the edges but the issues are very minor and the goods heavily outweigh the bads.

Here's a list of great features which ChilloutVR has:
[list]
[*]Great performance both in Desktop and VR.
[*]Content Filter system allowing you to hide avatars based on tags (Flashing Colors, NSFW, Gore etc etc).
[*]Dynamic Bones are networked so you can play with each other's dynamic bones without the need to use any clients.
[*]No Trust system or ranks, everyone has the same nameplate.
[*]You can have a picture next to your nameplate for free.
[*]No favorite slot limits and no avatar cloning, instead there is avatar sharing and there are no limits to it.
[*]You can fly.
[*]Proper multithreading thanks to which worlds and avatars are loading in the background.
[*]You can predownload worlds to have them ready for later without the need of actually going into them.
[*]The UI can be fully modified however you want since it's handled via HTML/CSS/JS.
[*]Pointers and Triggers which you can put on your avatar to physically interact with it. The cool thing is that the system is networked and cross avatar compatible so you can touch other people's triggers using your pointers.
[*]Prop System which allows you to upload interactive objects and spawn them in worlds without the need to put them on an avatar. You can spawn your props no matter which avatar you are using and other people can also interact with them.
[*]Advanced Avatar Settings which are allowing you to configure advanced controls like object toggles, material parameter changes and many many more. It comes with 100 parameter slots (no, it's not 128 bits like in VRC, it's legit 100 parameters).
[*]Colliders on avatars are supported so you can physically push people or lift them up.
[*]Particle Colliders also work so you can move people using your particles.
[*]Physics Materials are also supported so you can make a bouncy castle :)
[*]Particle Forcefields are fully networked so you can play with people's particles if they have External Forces enabled.
[/list]

Coming Soon:
[list]
[*]Modding Support will be coming in the future and will be natively supported by the game (once again no need for special clients).
[*]Future gamemode support (Newton scripting) with persistent data allowing you to save your progress and load it later on.
[*]Newton scripting will also be possible for avatars and props.
[*]Reserved instances which can run 24/7. You will have a whole control panel for them which will allow you to configure and control them in ways you have never seen before.
[*]Future inventory system which will support custom items generated in gamemodes. You will even be able to trade them.
[*]Future multi instance presence. If you are for example a DJ you will be able to appear in multiple instances at once.
[*]Future group system (sort of like guilds) allowing people to even host group based instances.
[*]Future event system which will allow you to host events and automatically invite everyone who signed up.
[*]Cross instance call service allowing you to call your friends or even groups of friends in different instances. While in a call a 3D projection of your friend(s) will appear in front of you. Sort of like Star Wars holograms.
[*]Natively supported secure video player. No more IP grabbing like in VRC, the video player will have trusted domains and a whitelist for unknown domains so nothing sketchy will play without your consent.
[*]Auto tagging of avatars for specific things like screen space shaders and other things which could be used in a malicious way.
[*]The ability to pass audio streams into the game. Good for listening to music with your friends and for DJs. You won't need to play it over your microphone or a twitch stream anymore.
[*]Anti crasher uploading. Yes soon people won't even be able to upload crashers.
[/list]

86259883.review:
After having a small login issue resolved due to some VRChat Fanboy DDOSing the servers, I hopped into CVR and joined an instance. I found myself playing for 7 and a half hours until my Index controllers were about to die. This game has an awful lot of potential. From my 1k hours in VRChat and 7.6 in this, I already see myself possibly permanently moving over to this.
So, the performance which a lot of people are curious of - It's great. In VRC, when looking at a high poly model with dynamic bones I find myself at 30-40fps (running on a 2080 super and R5 3600 btw), but in this wonderfully well optimised platform, I run at 80 to in the 100s. I have all avatars hidden in most lobbies in VRC, so having all of them shown was weird, but the lowest framerate I got was a 51. Sure, the optimisation could definitely be improved, but with the state that it's at, doesn't need to be at the top of the list just yet.

The content filter is great. Being able to properly hide what I want to hide is a pleasant feature. The part where avatars are automatically reviewed before being uploaded and malicious creations will never see the light of day is much appreciated, too. 
The community is overall very friendly and wholesome. I did run into one guy who started trying to sexualise me due to being a femboy (it's a lifestyle, it's just that some of us do sexual things and people see that as the norm, with is not true). The 2 moderators I ran into were chill and ready to answer my questions.

This game just released publicly, and even though it's been in private access with many updates prior, there is definitely a lot to do and a lot add. Flying is allowed for everyone, and allows you to fly at a good speed and noclip through anything. It would be ideal for world creators to have the ability to disallow this in their maps (for good reason). You currently aren't able to block people, but you can mute and hide their avatar.
Right off the bat after booting the game, I noticed my full body was quite off at the feet, pulling them forwards even after toying with the height. The bHaptics support is TERRIBLE. From what a moderator told me, the player has to be moving to activate the vest (I use the X40), and so when someone was to swipe up from my stomach to my next, it would be a very awkward moment of the vest jittering from on and off, missing most of the vibration motors entirely. I'm sure this will be better in the future, and please add a visual vest prefab that you can toggle hidden to make adding it to your avatar easier like in the VRC mod by HerpDerpenstine.
The CCK (the CVR Unity SDK) is pretty basic from what I've done with it. The ability to upload your own props is genius, although only you or a moderator can decide when to delete the prop, so this could definitely be exploited - not to mention the props collide with you and will push you around if big enough.
As I said, this social platform just released publicly, and I'm sure a lot of what I said above will be changed. I just wanted to explain what it's all like currently.

Overall, I really enjoyed - no - LOVED my experience so far with ChilloutVR, and will totally keep playing it, watching it evolve in all terms. I'm to get into map making, and look forward to using their coding language "Newton" to make some cool maps and even GAMEMODES as they promise they're going to add. From what I've heard, one of the devs plans on creating an MMO RPG, *ENTIRELY* in CVR.

If you just finished reading my review and are still deciding whether or not to get the game, stop. THE GAME IS FREE. Try it out for an hour or 2 and see if it's worth your time. I'm sure it will be worth it :)
